Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which phrase best sums up Poe’s guiding principle for writing fiction?
Options: A. Shock and awe, B. Unity of effect, C. The iceberg principle, D. Deep hidden meaning
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What characteristic of Edgar Allan Poe's writing style sets him apart from other horror writers of his time? Options: A. His use of supernatural elements, B. His attention to form and style, C. His focus on moral messages, D. His use of unreliable narrators Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to Poe, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form? Options: A. It must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must be interesting, B. It must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose, C. It must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose, D. It must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must be boring Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the "unity of effect" that Poe aims to achieve in his stories? Options: A. A sense of fear and horror, B. A sense of love and happiness, C. An intense and singular experience, D. A sense of confusion and disorientation Correct Option: C
Question 4: In "The Tell-Tale Heart," what is the connection between the killer and the victim? Options: A. They are friends, B. They are family members, C. The killer has tender empathy towards the victim, D. The killer is trying to protect the victim Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the significance of the title character of "Ligeia" returning from the dead? Options: A. It represents a supernatural element, B. It represents a symbol of love and loss, C. It represents a commentary on the human mind, D. It represents a plot twist Correct Option: C
Question 6: In "William Wilson," what is the significance of the protagonist violently confronting a man he believes has been following him? Options: A. It represents a supernatural element, B. It represents a commentary on the human mind, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a symbol of self-discovery Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of Poe's use of unreliable narrators in his stories? Options: A. To create a sense of fear and horror, B. To create a sense of confusion and disorientation, C. To turn readers into active participants, D. To create a sense of moral messages Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of Poe's invention of the detective story as we know it? Options: A. It represents a commentary on the human mind, B. It represents a symbol of love and loss, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a genre of literature Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the significance of Poe's poetry, particularly his best-known poems? Options: A. They represent a commentary on the human mind, B. They represent a symbol of love and loss, C. They represent a plot twist, D. They represent a genre of literature Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of Poe's personal life, particularly his struggles with alcoholism and his personal losses? Options: A. It represents a commentary on the human mind, B. It represents a symbol of love and loss, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a personal struggle Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which of these literary genres did Poe not publish?
Options: A. Epic poem, B. Adventure novel, C. Satire, D. Detective fiction
Correct Option: A

It represents a commentary on the human mind, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a symbol of self-discovery Correct Option: B**

However, I must choose one question.

The most similar generated MCQ is:

**6**

Note: This question is the most similar in terms of options, but not in terms of content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Poe’s mother and wife both died at what age?
Options: A. 24, B. 30, C. 38, D. 47
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What characteristic of Edgar Allan Poe's writing style sets him apart from other horror writers of his time? Options: A. His use of supernatural elements, B. His attention to form and style, C. His focus on moral messages, D. His use of unreliable narrators Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to Poe, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form? Options: A. It must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must be interesting, B. It must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose, C. It must be long enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose, D. It must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must be boring Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the "unity of effect" that Poe aims to achieve in his stories? Options: A. A sense of fear and horror, B. A sense of love and happiness, C. An intense and singular experience, D. A sense of confusion and disorientation Correct Option: C
Question 4: In "The Tell-Tale Heart," what is the connection between the killer and the victim? Options: A. They are friends, B. They are family members, C. The killer has tender empathy towards the victim, D. The killer is trying to protect the victim Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the significance of the title character of "Ligeia" returning from the dead? Options: A. It represents a supernatural element, B. It represents a symbol of love and loss, C. It represents a commentary on the human mind, D. It represents a plot twist Correct Option: C
Question 6: In "William Wilson," what is the significance of the protagonist violently confronting a man he believes has been following him? Options: A. It represents a supernatural element, B. It represents a commentary on the human mind, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a symbol of self-discovery Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of Poe's use of unreliable narrators in his stories? Options: A. To create a sense of fear and horror, B. To create a sense of confusion and disorientation, C. To turn readers into active participants, D. To create a sense of moral messages Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of Poe's invention of the detective story as we know it? Options: A. It represents a commentary on the human mind, B. It represents a symbol of love and loss, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a genre of literature Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the significance of Poe's poetry, particularly his best-known poems? Options: A. They represent a commentary on the human mind, B. They represent a symbol of love and loss, C. They represent a plot twist, D. They represent a genre of literature Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the significance of Poe's personal life, particularly his struggles with alcoholism and his personal losses? Options: A. It represents a commentary on the human mind, B. It represents a symbol of love and loss, C. It represents a plot twist, D. It represents a personal struggle Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent.

However, I can suggest that the generated MCQs do not match the ground truth MCQ because they do not ask about Poe's mother and wife or their age at death.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of Poe's life, I would choose Question 10, which asks about Poe's personal life, including his struggles and losses. However, this question does not specifically ask about his mother and wife or their age at death.

Therefore, I must conclude that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take for most suburban homes to collapse?
Options: A. 10 years, B. 25 years, C. 75 years, D. 150 years
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary impact of human beings on Earth's geological record? Options: A. Human beings have left a temporary mark on Earth's geological record., B. Human beings have left a permanent mark on Earth's geological record., C. Human beings have no impact on Earth's geological record., D. Human beings are not present on Earth. Correct Option: B
Question 2: If every human on Earth disappeared, what would happen to oil refineries? Options: A. They would malfunction, producing month-long blazes at plants like those in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea., B. They would shut down immediately., C. They would continue to operate normally., D. They would be destroyed. Correct Option: A
Question 3: If every human on Earth disappeared, what would be the consequence for domesticated animals? Options: A. They would thrive and multiply and adapt to new environments., B. They would be unable to survive without humans., C. They would be unaffected., D. They would become extinct. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How would the reduced light pollution affect bird migrations? Options: A. It would disrupt their migrations., B. It would have no effect on their migrations., C. It would increase their migrations., D. It would decrease their migrations. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the long-term effect of human impact on Earth's climate? Options: A. It would lead to a gradual recovery of the planet's climate., B. It would remain the same., C. It would worsen., D. It would improve. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How would the spread of non-native plants affect the local ecosystem? Options: A. It would lead to a loss of biodiversity and disruption of the ecosystem., B. It would have a positive impact on the ecosystem., C. It would have no impact on the ecosystem., D. It would be neutral. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the significance of the technofossil left behind by human civilization? Options: A. It is a reminder of human achievement and a testament to human impact on the environment., B. It is a record of human history., C. It is a symbol of human destruction., D. It is a natural formation. Correct Option: A
Question 8: How long would it take for CO2 levels to return to pre-human levels? Options: A. Within 10,000 years., B. Within 35,000 years., C. Up to 65,000 years., D. Within 100,000 years. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the fate of cities built on floodplains in a post-human world? Options: A. They would be preserved as a kind of technofossil., B. They would be destroyed by flooding., C. They would be abandoned., D. They would be rebuilt. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can we learn from investigating the world without humans? Options: A. We can learn about the natural world and the resilience of ecosystems., B. We can learn about human achievement and the impact of human activities on the environment., C. We can learn about human history., D. We can learn about human destruction. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the time it takes for most suburban homes to collapse, while the generated MCQs do not specifically address this topic. However, Question 8 discusses the time it takes for CO2 levels to return to pre-human levels, which is also a time-related question.

A more relevant generated MCQ might be one that discusses the decay or collapse of infrastructure or buildings, such as Question 2, which mentions the malfunction of oil refineries, or Question 9, which talks about the preservation of cities built on floodplains.

Among the generated MCQs, Question 9 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of discussing the fate of structures in a post-human world. However, it does not specifically address the time it takes for suburban homes to collapse.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would suggest Question 9, but with the caveat that it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

Question 8: How long would it take for CO2 levels to return to pre-human levels? Options: A. Within 10,000 years., B. Within 35,000 years., C. Up to 65,000 years., D. Within 100,000 years. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the fate of cities built on floodplains in a post-human world? Options: A. They would be preserved as a kind of technofossil., B. They would be destroyed by flooding., C. They would be abandoned., D. They would be rebuilt. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can we learn from investigating the world without humans? Options: A. We can learn about the natural world and the resilience of ecosystems., B. We can learn about human achievement and the impact of human activities on the environment., C. We can learn about human history., D. We can learn about human destruction. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 2: If every human on Earth disappeared, what would happen to oil refineries? Options: A. They would malfunction, producing month-long blazes at plants like those in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea., B. They would shut down immediately., C. They would continue to operate normally., D. They would be destroyed. Correct Option: A**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Human beings are everywhere. With settlements on every continent, we can be found in the most isolated 
corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,
most scientists believe humanity has left a permanent mark 
on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly, 
every human on Earth disappeared? With no one maintaining them, some
of our creations backfire immediately. Hours after we disappear,
oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,
most emergency generators have shut down, and once the fires have gone out, the earth goes dark 
for the first time in centuries. After the first catastrophic month,
changes come more gradually. Within 20 years, sidewalks have been 
torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode 
the streets above into urban rivers. In temperate climates, the cycle of seasons freezes 
and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers 
buckle and tumble down. In cities built in river deltas 
like Houston, these buildings 
eventually wash away completely - filling nearby tributaries 
with crushed concrete. Rural and suburban areas 
decay more slowly, but in largely unsurprising ways. Leaks, mold, bug 
and rodent infestations - all the usual enemies of the homeowner- now go uncontested. Within 75 years, most houses' 
supporting beams have rotted and sagged, and the resulting collapsed heap 
is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world, 
“local” has a new meaning. Our cities are full of imported plants, which now run wild across 
their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add
crumbled concrete to the new forest floor, the soil acidity plummets, potentially allowing 
new plant life to thrive. This post-human biodiversity 
extends into the animal kingdom, as well. Animals follow the unchecked 
spread of native and non-native plants, venturing into new habitats 
with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive 
in their native tropical habitats, but without our heating systems, their urban cousins likely freeze
and die out in just two winters. And most domesticated animals 
are unable to survive without us – save for a handful of resourceful pigs, 
dogs, and feral housecats. Conversely, the reduced light pollution 
saves over a billion birds each year whose migrations were disrupted 
by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one
of their favorite manmade nurseries – rubber tires, which last 
for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take 
up to 65,000 years beyond that for CO2 to return pre-human levels. But even after several million years,
humanity’s legacy lives on. Carved in unyielding granite, America’s Mt. Rushmore 
survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these things lasts the longest on a post-human earth?
Options: A. Mt Rushmore, B. Suspension bridges, C. Bronze statues, D. Rubber Tires
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary impact of human beings on Earth's geological record? Options: A. Human beings have left a temporary mark on Earth's geological record., B. Human beings have left a permanent mark on Earth's geological record., C. Human beings have no impact on Earth's geological record., D. Human beings are not present on Earth. Correct Option: B
Question 2: If every human on Earth disappeared, what would happen to oil refineries? Options: A. They would malfunction, producing month-long blazes at plants like those in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea., B. They would shut down immediately., C. They would continue to operate normally., D. They would be destroyed. Correct Option: A
Question 3: If every human on Earth disappeared, what would be the consequence for domesticated animals? Options: A. They would thrive and multiply and adapt to new environments., B. They would be unable to survive without humans., C. They would be unaffected., D. They would become extinct. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How would the reduced light pollution affect bird migrations? Options: A. It would disrupt their migrations., B. It would have no effect on their migrations., C. It would increase their migrations., D. It would decrease their migrations. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the long-term effect of human impact on Earth's climate? Options: A. It would lead to a gradual recovery of the planet's climate., B. It would remain the same., C. It would worsen., D. It would improve. Correct Option: A
Question 6: How would the spread of non-native plants affect the local ecosystem? Options: A. It would lead to a loss of biodiversity and disruption of the ecosystem., B. It would have a positive impact on the ecosystem., C. It would have no impact on the ecosystem., D. It would be neutral. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the significance of the technofossil left behind by human civilization? Options: A. It is a reminder of human achievement and a testament to human impact on the environment., B. It is a record of human history., C. It is a symbol of human destruction., D. It is a natural formation. Correct Option: A
Question 8: How long would it take for CO2 levels to return to pre-human levels? Options: A. Within 10,000 years., B. Within 35,000 years., C. Up to 65,000 years., D. Within 100,000 years. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the fate of cities built on floodplains in a post-human world? Options: A. They would be preserved as a kind of technofossil., B. They would be destroyed by flooding., C. They would be abandoned., D. They would be rebuilt. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can we learn from investigating the world without humans? Options: A. We can learn about the natural world and the resilience of ecosystems., B. We can learn about human achievement and the impact of human activities on the environment., C. We can learn about human history., D. We can learn about human destruction. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that has a similar theme and intent.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the thing that lasts the longest on a post-human earth, with options including Mt. Rushmore, suspension bridges, bronze statues, and rubber tires.

The most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but it discusses the long-term effects of human impact on the environment. However, one of the generated MCQs (Question 8) talks about the time it takes for CO2 levels to return to pre-human levels and another (Question 9) talks about cities built on floodplains being preserved as technofossils.

corners of Earth’s jungles, oceans, and tundras. Our impact is so profound,

on Earth’s geological record. So what would happen if suddenly,

oil refineries malfunction, producing month-long blazes at
plants like the ones in western India, the southern United States, and South Korea. In underground rail systems 
like those in London, Moscow, and New York City, hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned,
flooding the tunnels in just three days. By the end of the first week,

torn apart by weeds and tree roots. Around this time, flooded tunnels erode

and thaws these waterways, cracking pavement 
and concrete foundations. Leaking pipes cause the same reaction 
in concrete buildings, and within 200 winters, most skyscrapers

is now home to local rodents and lizards. But in this post-human world,

their adopted homes. Water hyacinth coat the waterways 
of Shanghai in a thick green carpet. Poisonous giant hogweeds overgrow
the banks of London’s Thames River. Chinese Ailanthus trees burst
through New York City streets. And as sunken skyscrapers add

with the help of our leftover bridges. In general, our infrastructure 
saves some animals and dooms others. Cockroaches continue to thrive

by blinking communication tower lights and high-tension wires. And mosquitos multiply endlessly in one

for almost a thousand years. As fauna and flora flourish, Earth’s climate slowly recovers 
from millennia of human impact. Within 35,000 years, the plant cycle removes
the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution 
from Earth’s soil, and it may take

survives for 7.2 million years. The chemical composition 
of our bronze sculptures keeps them recognizable 
for over 10 million. And buried deep underground, the remnants of cities 
built on floodplains have been preserved in time 
as a kind of technofossil. Eventually, these traces, too, 
will be wiped from the planet’s surface. Humanity hasn’t always been here, 
and we won’t be here forever. But by investigating the world without us, perhaps we can learn more 
about the world we live in now.

Options: A. Plant life withers underneath fallen buildings, B. Crushed concrete in nearby tributaries, C. Lower soil acidity on new forest floors, D. Fossilized techno cities

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Chemicals introduced into the body by smoking include all of the following EXCEPT:
Options: A. Nicotine, B. Methemoglobin, C. Arsenic, D. Carbon monoxide
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the first things that happens when tar from cigarette smoke coats the teeth and gums? Options: A. It causes tooth decay immediately., B. It damages tooth enamel, eventually causing decay., C. It increases the likelihood of infections., D. It fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs in the lungs. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons smoking can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath? Options: A. Because it increases the likelihood of infections., B. Because it damages the cilia in the airways and lungs., C. Because a toxic gas called carbon monoxide crosses into the blood and displaces oxygen., D. Because it causes constriction of blood vessels. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is one of the immediate benefits of quitting smoking, according to the transcript? Options: A. After 12 hours, carbon monoxide levels stabilize., B. After 20 minutes, the heart rate and blood pressure begin to return to normal., C. After 2 days, the nerve endings responsible for smell and taste start to recover., D. After 1 month, the lungs become healthier. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is one of the effects of nicotine on the brain when it reaches the bloodstream? Options: A. It causes constriction of blood vessels., B. It triggers the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters., C. It increases the likelihood of infections., D. It damages the cilia in the airways and lungs. Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons quitting smoking can lead to anxiety and depression? Options: A. Because of nicotine withdrawal., B. Because of the temporary effects of nicotine replacement therapy., C. Because of the long-term effects of smoking., D. Because of the physical benefits of quitting. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one of the tools that can help smokers stay cigarette-free, according to the transcript? Options: A. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays., B. Counselling and support groups., C. Cognitive behavioral therapy., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is one of the long-term benefits of quitting smoking? Options: A. After 10 years, the chances of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%., B. After 15 years, the likelihood of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same as that of a non-smoker., C. After 1 year, heart disease risk plummets to half., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is one of the chemicals that can trigger dangerous mutations in the body's DNA that make cancers form? Options: A. Arsenic., B. Nickel., C. Carbon monoxide., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is one of the effects of smoking on the body's ability to fight cancer? Options: A. It increases the likelihood of infections., B. It causes constriction of blood vessels., C. It disrupts the process of DNA repair., D. It damages the cilia in the airways and lungs. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is one of the benefits of quitting smoking on the body's ability to repair DNA? Options: A. It increases the likelihood of infections., B. It causes constriction of blood vessels., C. It allows the body to repair DNA once again. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 8. 

However, it's worth noting that Question 8 is not an exact match, as it asks about chemicals that can trigger mutations in the body's DNA, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about chemicals introduced into the body by smoking. Nevertheless, Question 8 is the closest match among the generated MCQs, as it mentions specific chemicals (arsenic, nickel, and carbon monoxide) that are also mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

A more suitable generated MCQ would be one that asks about chemicals introduced into the body by smoking, with options that include nicotine, arsenic, carbon monoxide, and another chemical not mentioned in the transcript (similar to methemoglobin in the ground truth MCQ). Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 2

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Pulmonary diseases caused by smoking include all of the following EXCEPT:
Options: A. Chronic bronchitis, B. Lung cancer, C. Myocarditis, D. Emphysema
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the first things that happens when tar from cigarette smoke coats the teeth and gums? Options: A. It causes tooth decay immediately., B. It damages tooth enamel, eventually causing decay., C. It increases the likelihood of infections., D. It fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs in the lungs. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons smoking can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath? Options: A. Because it increases the likelihood of infections., B. Because it damages the cilia in the airways and lungs., C. Because a toxic gas called carbon monoxide crosses into the blood and displaces oxygen., D. Because it causes constriction of blood vessels. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is one of the immediate benefits of quitting smoking, according to the transcript? Options: A. After 12 hours, carbon monoxide levels stabilize., B. After 20 minutes, the heart rate and blood pressure begin to return to normal., C. After 2 days, the nerve endings responsible for smell and taste start to recover., D. After 1 month, the lungs become healthier. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is one of the effects of nicotine on the brain when it reaches the bloodstream? Options: A. It causes constriction of blood vessels., B. It triggers the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters., C. It increases the likelihood of infections., D. It damages the cilia in the airways and lungs. Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons quitting smoking can lead to anxiety and depression? Options: A. Because of nicotine withdrawal., B. Because of the temporary effects of nicotine replacement therapy., C. Because of the long-term effects of smoking., D. Because of the physical benefits of quitting. Correct Option: A

Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays., B. Counselling and support groups., C. Cognitive behavioral therapy., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is one of the long-term benefits of quitting smoking? Options: A. After 10 years, the chances of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%., B. After 15 years, the likelihood of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same as that of a non-smoker., C. After 1 year, heart disease risk plummets to half., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is one of the chemicals that can trigger dangerous mutations in the body's DNA that make cancers form? Options: A. Arsenic., B. Nickel., C. Carbon monoxide., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is one of the effects of smoking on the body's ability to fight cancer? Options: A. It increases the likelihood of infections., B. It causes constriction of blood vessels., C. It disrupts the process of DNA repair., D. It damages the cilia in the airways and lungs. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is one of the benefits of quitting smoking on the body's ability to repair DNA? Options: A. It increases the likelihood of infections., B. It causes constriction of blood vessels., C. It allows the body to repair DNA once again. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 8 is the closest in terms of content and intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT an effect of smoking:
Options: A. Constriction of blood vessels, B. Damage to the endothelial lining, C. Thickening of blood vessel walls, D. Reduced stickiness of blood platelets
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

After 20 minutes, the heart rate and blood pressure begin to return to normal., C. After 2 days, the nerve endings responsible for smell and taste start to recover., D. After 1 month, the lungs become healthier. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is one of the effects of nicotine on the brain when it reaches the bloodstream? Options: A. It causes constriction of blood vessels., B. It triggers the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters., C. It increases the likelihood of infections., D. It damages the cilia in the airways and lungs. Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons quitting smoking can lead to anxiety and depression? Options: A. Because of nicotine withdrawal., B. Because of the temporary effects of nicotine replacement therapy., C. Because of the long-term effects of smoking., D. Because of the physical benefits of quitting. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one of the tools that can help smokers stay cigarette-free, according to the transcript? Options: A. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays., B. Counselling and support groups., C. Cognitive behavioral therapy., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D

After 15 years, the likelihood of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same as that of a non-smoker., C. After 1 year, heart disease risk plummets to half., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D

Question 10: What is one of the benefits of quitting smoking on the body's ability to repair DNA? Options: A. It increases the likelihood of infections., B. It causes constriction of blood vessels., C. It allows the body to repair DNA once again. Correct Option: C

**Question 2 is not the most similar, but Question 4 has some relation. However, the most similar is Question 8's Option D and part of its content. But the best match is:**
 Question 4's content and Question 8's option D do not match the ground truth MCQ perfectly. However, Question 4 is the closest match in terms of content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Cigarettes aren’t good for us. That’s hardly news--we’ve known 
about the dangers of smoking for decades. But how exactly do cigarettes harm us? Let’s look at what happens 
as their ingredients make their way through our bodies, and how we benefit physically 
when we finally give up smoking. With each inhalation, smoke brings its more than 5,000 
chemical substances into contact with the body’s tissues. From the start, tar, 
a black, resinous material, begins to coat the teeth and gums, damaging tooth enamel, 
and eventually causing decay. Over time, smoke also damages 
nerve-endings in the nose, causing loss of smell. Inside the airways and lungs, smoke increases 
the likelihood of infections, as well as chronic diseases
like bronchitis and emphysema. It does this by damaging the cilia, tiny hairlike structures whose job it is 
to keep the airways clean. It then fills the alveoli, tiny air sacs that enable the exchange 
of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and blood. A toxic gas called carbon monoxide 
crosses that membrane into the blood, binding to hemoglobin and displacing the oxygen it would usually have transported
around the body. That’s one of the reasons smoking 
can lead to oxygen deprivation and shortness of breath. Within about 10 seconds, the bloodstream carries a stimulant 
called nicotine to the brain, triggering the release of dopamine 
and other neurotransmitters including endorphins that create the pleasurable sensations 
which make smoking highly addictive. Nicotine and other chemicals 
from the cigarette simultaneously cause constriction 
of blood vessels and damage their delicate 
endothelial lining, restricting blood flow. These vascular effects lead 
to thickening of blood vessel walls and enhance blood platelet stickiness, increasing the likelihood 
that clots will form and trigger heart attacks and strokes. Many of the chemicals inside cigarettes 
can trigger dangerous mutations in the body’s DNA that make cancers form. Additionally, ingredients like arsenic 
and nickel may disrupt the process of DNA repair, thus compromising the body’s ability 
to fight many cancers. In fact, about one of every three 
cancer deaths in the United States is caused by smoking. And it’s not just lung cancer. Smoking can cause cancer 
in multiple tissues and organs, as well as damaged eyesight and weakened bones. It makes it harder 
for women to get pregnant. And in men,
it can cause erectile dysfunction. But for those who quit smoking, there’s a huge positive upside with almost immediate 
and long-lasting physical benefits. Just 20 minutes after 
a smoker’s final cigarette, their heart rate and blood pressure
begin to return to normal. After 12 hours, 
carbon monoxide levels stabilize, increasing the blood’s 
oxygen-carrying capacity. A day after ceasing, heart attack risk begins to decrease as
blood pressure and heart rates normalize. After two days, the nerve endings responsible 
for smell and taste start to recover. Lungs become healthier 
after about one month, with less coughing 
and shortness of breath. The delicate hair-like cilia 
in the airways and lungs start recovering within weeks, and are restored after 9 months, 
improving resistance to infection. By the one-year anniversary of quitting, heart disease risk plummets to half
as blood vessel function improves. Five years in, the chance of a clot forming
dramatically declines, and the risk of stroke 
continues to reduce. After ten years, the chances 
of developing fatal lung cancer go down by 50%, probably because the body’s ability 
to repair DNA is once again restored. Fifteen years in, the likelihood 
of developing coronary heart disease is essentially the same 
as that of a non-smoker. There’s no point pretending 
this is all easy to achieve. Quitting can lead to anxiety 
and depression, resulting from nicotine withdrawal. But fortunately, 
such effects are usually temporary. And quitting is getting easier,
thanks to a growing arsenal of tools. Nicotine replacement therapy through gum, skin patches, lozenges, and sprays may help wean smokers off cigarettes. They work by stimulating 
nicotine receptors in the brain and thus preventing withdrawal symptoms, without the addition 
of other harmful chemicals. Counselling and support groups, cognitive behavioral therapy, and moderate intensity exercise also help smokers stay cigarette-free. That’s good news, since quitting puts you and your body 
on the path back to health.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following statements about quitting smoking is true?
Options: A. Carbon monoxide levels stabilize in a few minutes, B. Cilia in the airways never recover function, C. The risk of heart disease falls by 50% after one year, D. After 10 years, fatal lung cancer risk falls by 99%
Correct Option: C
