Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the year 1066, 7000 Norman infantry and knights sailed 
in warships across the English Channel. Their target: England, 
home to more than a million people. Theirs was a short voyage
with massive consequences. And around the same period of time, other groups of Normans
were setting forth all across Europe, going on adventures that would reverberate
throughout that continent’s history. So who were these warriors and how did they leave 
their mark so far and wide? Our story begins 
over 200 years earlier, when Vikings began to settle 
on the shores of northern France as part of a great Scandinavian exodus 
across northern Europe. The French locals called 
these invaders Normans, named for the direction they came from. Eventually, Charles, 
the king of the Franks, negotiated peace with 
the Viking leader Rollo in 911, granting him a stretch of land 
along France’s northern coast that came to be known as Normandy. The Normans proved adaptable
to their newly settled life. They married Frankish women, adopted the French language, and soon started converting 
from Norse paganism to Christianity. But though they adapted, they maintained the warrior tradition and conquering spirit 
of their Viking forebears. Before long, ambitious Norman knights 
were looking for new challenges. The Normans’ best-known achievement 
was their conquest of England. In 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy, disputed the claim of 
the new English king, Harold Godwinson. Soon after landing in England, William and his knights met Harold’s army 
near the town of Hastings. The climactic moment in the battle is immortalized in 
the 70-meter-long Bayeux Tapestry, where an arrow striking Harold 
in the eye seals the Norman victory. William consolidated his gains 
with a huge castle-building campaign and a reorganization of English society. He lived up to his nickname 
"William the Conqueror" through a massive survey
known as the Domesday Book, which recorded the population
and ownership of every piece of land in England. Norman French became the language 
of the new royal court, while commoners continued 
to speak Anglo-Saxon. Over time, the two merged 
to give us the English we know today, though the divide between lords 
and peasants can still be felt in synonym pairs such as cow and beef. By the end of the 12th century, the Normans had further expanded 
into Wales, Scotland, and Ireland. Meanwhile, independent groups 
of Norman knights traveled to the Mediterranean, inspired by tales of pilgrims 
returning from Jerusalem. There, they threw themselves 
into a tangled mass of conflicts among the established powers 
all over that region. They became highly prized mercenaries, and during one of these battles, they made the first recorded 
heavy cavalry charge with couched lances, a devastating tactic that soon became 
standard in medieval warfare. The Normans were also central 
to the First Crusade of 1095-99, a bloody conflict that re-established
Christian control in certain parts of the Middle East. But the Normans did more than just fight. As a result of their victories, leaders like William Iron-Arm 
and Robert the Crafty secured lands throughout Southern Italy, eventually merging them
to form the Kingdom of Sicily in 1130. Under Roger II, the kingdom became a beacon of
multicultural tolerance in a world torn apart 
by religious and civil wars. Muslim Arab poets and scholars 
served in the royal court alongside Byzantine Greek sailors 
and architects. Arabic remained an official language along
with Latin, Greek, and Norman French. The world’s geographical knowledge 
was compiled in The Book of Roger, whose maps of the known world would remain the most accurate 
available for 300 years. And the churches built in Palermo
combined Latin-style architecture, Arab ceilings, and Byzantine domes, all decorated with
exquisite golden mosaics. So if the Normans were so successful,
why aren’t they still around? In fact, this was a key part of
their success: not just ruling the societies 
they conquered, but becoming part of them. Although the Normans eventually 
disappeared as a distinct group, their contributions remained. And today, from the castles and
cathedrals that dot Europe’s landscape to wherever 
the English language is spoken, the Norman legacy lives on.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where did the original Normans come from?
Options: A. Normandy, B. Scandinavia, C. Norway, D. England
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who were the Viking invaders that settled on the shores of northern France and eventually became known as the Normans? Options: A. The Franks, B. The Saxons, C. The Vikings, D. The Norse settlers Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the name of the treaty between Charles, the king of the Franks, and Rollo, the Viking leader, in 911? Options: A. The Treaty of Hastings, B. The Treaty of Normandy, C. The Treaty of St. Clair-sur-Epte, D. The Treaty of Rouen Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the name of the massive survey conducted by William the Conqueror to record the population and ownership of every piece of land in England? Options: A. The Domesday Book, B. The Bayeux Tapestry, C. The Norman Conquest, D. The Treaty of Normandy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the result of the battle immortalized in the 70-meter-long Bayeux Tapestry? Options: A. The defeat of the Normans, B. The victory of the Normans, C. The stalemate between the Normans and the English, D. The withdrawal of both armies Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the impact of the Norman Conquest on the English language? Options: A. It led to the disappearance of the English language, B. It led to the replacement of the English language with Norman French, C. It led to the merger of Anglo-Saxon and Norman French to form the English language, D. It had no impact on the English language Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the role of the Normans in the First Crusade of 1095-99? Options: A. They were the leaders of the Crusade, B. They were the main opponents of the Crusade, C. They were central to the Crusade and helped re-establish Christian control in certain parts of the Middle East, D. They had no role in the Crusade Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the significance of the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger II? Options: A. It was a major military power in the Mediterranean, B. It was a center of learning and culture, C. It was a beacon of multicultural tolerance in a world torn apart by religious and civil wars, D. It was a major trading hub Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the key to the success of the Normans? Options: A. Their military power, B. Their cultural superiority, C. Their ability to adapt to the societies they conquered and become part of them, D. Their economic power and wealth Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the legacy of the Normans today? Options: A. They are still a distinct group and a major power in Europe, B. They have disappeared as a distinct group but their contributions remain, C. They have no legacy and are forgotten, D. They are remembered only for their military conquests Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of The Book of Roger? Options: A. It was a major work of literature, B. It was a major military strategy book, C. It was a compilation of the world's geographical knowledge and maps of the known world, D. It was a major historical document Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the wording of the question is different, the intent and content of Question 1 are similar to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions are asking about the origin of the Normans. The correct option in Question 1 is "The Vikings", which is equivalent to option B "Scandinavia" in the ground truth MCQ, as the Vikings came from Scandinavia.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the year 1066, 7000 Norman infantry and knights sailed 
in warships across the English Channel. Their target: England, 
home to more than a million people. Theirs was a short voyage
with massive consequences. And around the same period of time, other groups of Normans
were setting forth all across Europe, going on adventures that would reverberate
throughout that continent’s history. So who were these warriors and how did they leave 
their mark so far and wide? Our story begins 
over 200 years earlier, when Vikings began to settle 
on the shores of northern France as part of a great Scandinavian exodus 
across northern Europe. The French locals called 
these invaders Normans, named for the direction they came from. Eventually, Charles, 
the king of the Franks, negotiated peace with 
the Viking leader Rollo in 911, granting him a stretch of land 
along France’s northern coast that came to be known as Normandy. The Normans proved adaptable
to their newly settled life. They married Frankish women, adopted the French language, and soon started converting 
from Norse paganism to Christianity. But though they adapted, they maintained the warrior tradition and conquering spirit 
of their Viking forebears. Before long, ambitious Norman knights 
were looking for new challenges. The Normans’ best-known achievement 
was their conquest of England. In 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy, disputed the claim of 
the new English king, Harold Godwinson. Soon after landing in England, William and his knights met Harold’s army 
near the town of Hastings. The climactic moment in the battle is immortalized in 
the 70-meter-long Bayeux Tapestry, where an arrow striking Harold 
in the eye seals the Norman victory. William consolidated his gains 
with a huge castle-building campaign and a reorganization of English society. He lived up to his nickname 
"William the Conqueror" through a massive survey
known as the Domesday Book, which recorded the population
and ownership of every piece of land in England. Norman French became the language 
of the new royal court, while commoners continued 
to speak Anglo-Saxon. Over time, the two merged 
to give us the English we know today, though the divide between lords 
and peasants can still be felt in synonym pairs such as cow and beef. By the end of the 12th century, the Normans had further expanded 
into Wales, Scotland, and Ireland. Meanwhile, independent groups 
of Norman knights traveled to the Mediterranean, inspired by tales of pilgrims 
returning from Jerusalem. There, they threw themselves 
into a tangled mass of conflicts among the established powers 
all over that region. They became highly prized mercenaries, and during one of these battles, they made the first recorded 
heavy cavalry charge with couched lances, a devastating tactic that soon became 
standard in medieval warfare. The Normans were also central 
to the First Crusade of 1095-99, a bloody conflict that re-established
Christian control in certain parts of the Middle East. But the Normans did more than just fight. As a result of their victories, leaders like William Iron-Arm 
and Robert the Crafty secured lands throughout Southern Italy, eventually merging them
to form the Kingdom of Sicily in 1130. Under Roger II, the kingdom became a beacon of
multicultural tolerance in a world torn apart 
by religious and civil wars. Muslim Arab poets and scholars 
served in the royal court alongside Byzantine Greek sailors 
and architects. Arabic remained an official language along
with Latin, Greek, and Norman French. The world’s geographical knowledge 
was compiled in The Book of Roger, whose maps of the known world would remain the most accurate 
available for 300 years. And the churches built in Palermo
combined Latin-style architecture, Arab ceilings, and Byzantine domes, all decorated with
exquisite golden mosaics. So if the Normans were so successful,
why aren’t they still around? In fact, this was a key part of
their success: not just ruling the societies 
they conquered, but becoming part of them. Although the Normans eventually 
disappeared as a distinct group, their contributions remained. And today, from the castles and
cathedrals that dot Europe’s landscape to wherever 
the English language is spoken, the Norman legacy lives on.

home to more than a million people. Theirs was a short voyage
with massive consequences. And around the same period of time, other groups of Normans
were setting forth all across Europe, going on adventures that would reverberate
throughout that continent’s history. So who were these warriors and how did they leave 
their mark so far and wide? Our story begins 
over 200 years earlier, when Vikings began to settle 
on the shores of northern France as part of a great Scandinavian exodus 
across northern Europe. The French locals called 
these invaders Normans, named for the direction they came from. Eventually, Charles, 
the king of the Franks, negotiated peace with

along France’s northern coast that came to be known as Normandy. The Normans proved adaptable
to their newly settled life. They married Frankish women, adopted the French language, and soon started converting 
from Norse paganism to Christianity. But though they adapted, they maintained the warrior tradition and conquering spirit 
of their Viking forebears. Before long, ambitious Norman knights 
were looking for new challenges. The Normans’ best-known achievement 
was their conquest of England. In 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy, disputed the claim of 
the new English king, Harold Godwinson. Soon after landing in England, William and his knights met Harold’s army 
near the town of Hastings. The climactic moment in the battle is immortalized in 
the 70-meter-long Bayeux Tapestry, where an arrow striking Harold 
in the eye seals the Norman victory. William consolidated his gains 
with a huge castle-building campaign and a reorganization of English society. He lived up to his nickname 
"William the Conqueror" through a massive survey
known as the Domesday Book, which recorded the population
and ownership of every piece of land in England. Norman French became the language 
of the new royal court, while commoners continued 
to speak Anglo-Saxon. Over time, the two merged 
to give us the English we know today, though the divide between lords

into Wales, Scotland, and Ireland. Meanwhile, independent groups 
of Norman knights traveled to the Mediterranean, inspired by tales of pilgrims 
returning from Jerusalem. There, they threw themselves 
into a tangled mass of conflicts among the established powers 
all over that region. They became highly prized mercenaries, and during one of these battles, they made the first recorded

the English language is spoken, the Norman legacy lives on.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the purpose of the Domesday Book?
Options: A. To carry out a census of all the conquered English peoples, B. To reorganize the English legal system along Norman lines, C. To record the details of how the Normans won the battle of Hastings, D. To record the population and ownership of every piece of land in England
Correct Option: D

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why was the Norman kingdom of Sicily considered a beacon of tolerance?
Options: A. King Roger II employed Arabs, Byzantine Greeks, and Normans in his government, B. It was illegal to discriminate against other races, C. King Roger II signed treaties with all leading powers of the medieval era, D. King Roger II encouraged exploration of the New World
Correct Option: A

King Roger II employed Arabs, Byzantine Greeks, and Normans in his government). Both options convey the idea that the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger II was notable for its tolerance and multiculturalism. 

While the wording of the questions and options is not identical, the overall content and intent are similar, making Question 7 the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the year 1066, 7000 Norman infantry and knights sailed 
in warships across the English Channel. Their target: England, 
home to more than a million people. Theirs was a short voyage
with massive consequences. And around the same period of time, other groups of Normans
were setting forth all across Europe, going on adventures that would reverberate
throughout that continent’s history. So who were these warriors and how did they leave 
their mark so far and wide? Our story begins 
over 200 years earlier, when Vikings began to settle 
on the shores of northern France as part of a great Scandinavian exodus 
across northern Europe. The French locals called 
these invaders Normans, named for the direction they came from. Eventually, Charles, 
the king of the Franks, negotiated peace with 
the Viking leader Rollo in 911, granting him a stretch of land 
along France’s northern coast that came to be known as Normandy. The Normans proved adaptable
to their newly settled life. They married Frankish women, adopted the French language, and soon started converting 
from Norse paganism to Christianity. But though they adapted, they maintained the warrior tradition and conquering spirit 
of their Viking forebears. Before long, ambitious Norman knights 
were looking for new challenges. The Normans’ best-known achievement 
was their conquest of England. In 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy, disputed the claim of 
the new English king, Harold Godwinson. Soon after landing in England, William and his knights met Harold’s army 
near the town of Hastings. The climactic moment in the battle is immortalized in 
the 70-meter-long Bayeux Tapestry, where an arrow striking Harold 
in the eye seals the Norman victory. William consolidated his gains 
with a huge castle-building campaign and a reorganization of English society. He lived up to his nickname 
"William the Conqueror" through a massive survey
known as the Domesday Book, which recorded the population
and ownership of every piece of land in England. Norman French became the language 
of the new royal court, while commoners continued 
to speak Anglo-Saxon. Over time, the two merged 
to give us the English we know today, though the divide between lords 
and peasants can still be felt in synonym pairs such as cow and beef. By the end of the 12th century, the Normans had further expanded 
into Wales, Scotland, and Ireland. Meanwhile, independent groups 
of Norman knights traveled to the Mediterranean, inspired by tales of pilgrims 
returning from Jerusalem. There, they threw themselves 
into a tangled mass of conflicts among the established powers 
all over that region. They became highly prized mercenaries, and during one of these battles, they made the first recorded 
heavy cavalry charge with couched lances, a devastating tactic that soon became 
standard in medieval warfare. The Normans were also central 
to the First Crusade of 1095-99, a bloody conflict that re-established
Christian control in certain parts of the Middle East. But the Normans did more than just fight. As a result of their victories, leaders like William Iron-Arm 
and Robert the Crafty secured lands throughout Southern Italy, eventually merging them
to form the Kingdom of Sicily in 1130. Under Roger II, the kingdom became a beacon of
multicultural tolerance in a world torn apart 
by religious and civil wars. Muslim Arab poets and scholars 
served in the royal court alongside Byzantine Greek sailors 
and architects. Arabic remained an official language along
with Latin, Greek, and Norman French. The world’s geographical knowledge 
was compiled in The Book of Roger, whose maps of the known world would remain the most accurate 
available for 300 years. And the churches built in Palermo
combined Latin-style architecture, Arab ceilings, and Byzantine domes, all decorated with
exquisite golden mosaics. So if the Normans were so successful,
why aren’t they still around? In fact, this was a key part of
their success: not just ruling the societies 
they conquered, but becoming part of them. Although the Normans eventually 
disappeared as a distinct group, their contributions remained. And today, from the castles and
cathedrals that dot Europe’s landscape to wherever 
the English language is spoken, the Norman legacy lives on.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happened to the Normans in the end?
Options: A. They were eventually defeated in battle, B. They surrendered to the authority of the Pope, C. They merged into the societies that they conquered, D. They retreated back to their homeland
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who were the Viking invaders that settled on the shores of northern France and eventually became known as the Normans? Options: A. The Franks, B. The Saxons, C. The Vikings, D. The Norse settlers Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the name of the treaty between Charles, the king of the Franks, and Rollo, the Viking leader, in 911? Options: A. The Treaty of Hastings, B. The Treaty of Normandy, C. The Treaty of St. Clair-sur-Epte, D. The Treaty of Rouen Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the name of the massive survey conducted by William the Conqueror to record the population and ownership of every piece of land in England? Options: A. The Domesday Book, B. The Bayeux Tapestry, C. The Norman Conquest, D. The Treaty of Normandy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the result of the battle immortalized in the 70-meter-long Bayeux Tapestry? Options: A. The defeat of the Normans, B. The victory of the Normans, C. The stalemate between the Normans and the English, D. The withdrawal of both armies Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the impact of the Norman Conquest on the English language? Options: A. It led to the disappearance of the English language, B. It led to the replacement of the English language with Norman French, C. It led to the merger of Anglo-Saxon and Norman French to form the English language, D. It had no impact on the English language Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the role of the Normans in the First Crusade of 1095-99? Options: A. They were the leaders of the Crusade, B. They were the main opponents of the Crusade, C. They were central to the Crusade and helped re-establish Christian control in certain parts of the Middle East, D. They had no role in the Crusade Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the significance of the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger II? Options: A. It was a major military power in the Mediterranean, B. It was a center of learning and culture, C. It was a beacon of multicultural tolerance in a world torn apart by religious and civil wars, D. It was a major trading hub Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the key to the success of the Normans? Options: A. Their military power, B. Their cultural superiority, C. Their ability to adapt to the societies they conquered and become part of them, D. Their economic power and wealth Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the legacy of the Normans today? Options: A. They are still a distinct group and a major power in Europe, B. They have disappeared as a distinct group but their contributions remain, C. They have no legacy and are forgotten, D. They are remembered only for their military conquests Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of The Book of Roger? Options: A. It was a major work of literature, B. It was a major military strategy book, C. It was a compilation of the world's geographical knowledge and maps of the known world, D. It was a major historical document Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the ultimate fate or key to the success of the Normans, and both have options that mention the Normans becoming part of the societies they conquered. The correct options for both questions also match, stating that the Normans' ability to adapt and become part of the societies they conquered was a key factor in their success. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 8.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Three people are at a dinner party. Paul, who’s married, is looking at Linda. Meanwhile, Linda is looking at John, 
who’s not married. Is someone who’s married looking 
at someone who’s not married? Take a moment to think about it. Most people answer that there’s 
not enough information to tell. And most people are wrong. Linda must be either married 
or not married—there are no other options. So in either scenario, someone married 
is looking at someone who’s not married. When presented with the explanation, 
most people change their minds and accept the correct answer, despite being very confident 
in their first responses. Now let’s look at another case. A 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan 
and Jason Reifler examined American attitudes regarding 
the justifications for the Iraq War. Researchers presented participants 
with a news article that showed no weapons 
of mass destruction had been found. Yet many participants not only continued 
to believe that WMDs had been found, but they even became more convinced 
of their original views. So why do arguments change people’s minds 
in some cases and backfire in others? Arguments are more convincing when they 
rest on a good knowledge of the audience, taking into account 
what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value. Mathematical and logical arguments 
like the dinner party brainteaser work because even when people 
reach different conclusions, they’re starting from 
the same set of shared beliefs. In 1931, a young, unknown mathematician 
named Kurt Gödel presented a proof that a logically complete
system of mathematics was impossible. Despite upending decades of
work by brilliant mathematicians like Bertrand Russell and David Hilbert, the proof was accepted because it relied on axioms that 
everyone in the field already agreed on. Of course, many disagreements involve 
different beliefs that can’t simply be reconciled
through logic. When these beliefs involve 
outside information, the issue often comes down to
what sources and authorities people trust. One study asked people to estimate 
several statistics related to the scope of climate change. Participants were asked questions, such as “how many of the years 
between 1995 and 2006 were one of the hottest 12 years 
since 1850?” After providing their answers, they were presented with data from the
Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, in this case showing that the answer 
was 11 of the 12 years. Being provided with these reliable 
statistics from a trusted official source made people more likely to accept 
the reality that the earth is warming. Finally, for disagreements that 
can’t be definitively settled with statistics or evidence, making a convincing argument may depend on engaging 
the audience’s values. For example, researchers have conducted 
a number of studies where they’ve asked people 
of different political backgrounds to rank their values. Liberals in these studies, 
on average, rank fairness— here meaning whether everyone is treated 
in the same way—above loyalty. In later studies, researchers attempted 
to convince liberals to support military spending with 
a variety of arguments. Arguments based on fairness— like that the military provides employment and education to people 
from disadvantaged backgrounds— were more convincing than arguments 
based on loyalty— such as that the military 
unifies a nation. These three elements— beliefs, trusted sources, and values— may seem like a simple formula 
for finding agreement and consensus. The problem is that our initial 
inclination is to think of arguments that rely on our own beliefs, 
trusted sources, and values. And even when we don’t, it can be challenging to correctly 
identify what’s held dear by people who don’t already agree with us. The best way to find out
is simply to talk to them. In the course of discussion, you’ll be exposed to counter-arguments
and rebuttals. These can help you make your own 
arguments and reasoning more convincing and sometimes, you may even end up 
being the one changing your mind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Frequently, what elements must an argument take into account to be convincing?
Options: A. A person's beliefs, B. Trusted sources, C. A person's values, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the outcome when most people are presented with the explanation of the dinner party scenario? Options: A. They still disagree with the correct answer., B. They become even more confident in their original views., C. They change their minds and accept the correct answer., D. They are unable to make a decision. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why arguments based on mathematical and logical reasoning are effective? Options: A. They appeal to people's emotions., B. They rely on a good knowledge of the audience's values., C. They rely on a good knowledge of the audience's beliefs., D. They are presented in a visually appealing format. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the outcome of a 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan and Jason Reifler regarding American attitudes towards the Iraq War? Options: A. Participants became less convinced of their original views., B. Participants' views remained unchanged., C. Participants became more convinced of their original views., D. The study found no correlation between views and arguments. Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the key to making a convincing argument when dealing with disagreements that involve different beliefs? Options: A. Appealing to people's emotions., B. Relying on a good knowledge of the audience's values., C. Presenting evidence from trusted sources., D. Using logical reasoning. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the main difference between liberals and conservatives in terms of their values, according to the transcript? Options: A. Liberals prioritize loyalty over fairness, while conservatives prioritize fairness over loyalty., B. Liberals prioritize fairness over loyalty, while conservatives prioritize loyalty over fairness., C. Liberals and conservatives have the same values., D. The difference is not specified in the transcript. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the best way to find out what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us, according to the transcript? Options: A. By reading their written opinions., B. By engaging in online discussions., C. By talking to them directly., D. By analyzing their social media profiles. Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of being exposed to counter-arguments and rebuttals in the course of discussion? Options: A. We become more entrenched in our original views., B. We are unable to change our minds., C. We make our own arguments and reasoning more convincing., D. We become less confident in our opinions. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary reason why Kurt Gödel's proof was accepted by mathematicians in 1931? Options: A. It relied on axioms that everyone in the field already agreed on., B. It was presented in a visually appealing format., C. It appealed to people's emotions., D. It was based on personal opinions. Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of being provided with reliable statistics from a trusted official source, such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change? Options: A. People become less likely to accept the reality of climate change., B. People's views remain unchanged., C. People become more likely to accept the reality of climate change., D. The outcome is not specified in the transcript. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main point of the transcript regarding the importance of understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us? Options: A. It is not important to understand what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us., B. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is a simple process., C. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is crucial for making convincing arguments., D. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is not a key factor in making convincing arguments. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the key to making a convincing argument when dealing with disagreements that involve different beliefs? Options: A. Appealing to people's emotions., B. Relying on a good knowledge of the audience's values., C. Presenting evidence from trusted sources., D. Using logical reasoning. Correct Option: C**

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only mentions one aspect of making a convincing argument (presenting evidence from trusted sources), whereas the ground truth MCQ mentions three elements: a person's beliefs, trusted sources, and a person's values.

A closer match would be a question that includes all three elements. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose the most similar one, I would suggest:

**Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why arguments based on mathematical and logical reasoning are effective? Options: A. They appeal to people's emotions., B. They rely on a good knowledge of the audience's values., C. They rely on a good knowledge of the audience's beliefs., D. They are presented in a visually appealing format. Correct Option: C**

This question mentions one of the elements (a person's beliefs), but not the other two (trusted sources and a person's values). However, it is the closest match among the generated MCQs.

If I had to provide an index, I would suggest: **2** (with the caveat that it's not a perfect match).

However, I must emphasize that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, and a new question that includes all three elements (a person's beliefs, trusted sources, and a person's values) would be a better match.

Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Three people are at a dinner party. Paul, who’s married, is looking at Linda. Meanwhile, Linda is looking at John, 
who’s not married. Is someone who’s married looking 
at someone who’s not married? Take a moment to think about it. Most people answer that there’s

with a news article that showed no weapons 
of mass destruction had been found. Yet many participants not only continued 
to believe that WMDs had been found, but they even became more convinced 
of their original views. So why do arguments change people’s minds 
in some cases and backfire in others? Arguments are more convincing when they

identify what’s held dear by people who don’t already agree with us. The best way to find out
is simply to talk to them. In the course of discussion, you’ll be exposed to counter-arguments
and rebuttals. These can help you make your own 
arguments and reasoning more convincing and sometimes, you may even end up 
being the one changing your mind.

Correct Option: B

The difference is not specified in the transcript. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the best way to find out what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us, according to the transcript? Options: A. By reading their written opinions., B. By engaging in online discussions., C. By talking to them directly., D. By analyzing their social media profiles. Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of being exposed to counter-arguments and rebuttals in the course of discussion? Options: A. We become more entrenched in our original views., B. We are unable to change our minds., C. We make our own arguments and reasoning more convincing., D. We become less confident in our opinions. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary reason why Kurt Gödel's proof was accepted by mathematicians in 1931? Options: A. It relied on axioms that everyone in the field already agreed on., B. It was presented in a visually appealing format., C. It appealed to people's emotions., D. It was based on personal opinions. Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of being provided with reliable statistics from a trusted official source, such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change? Options: A. People become less likely to accept the reality of climate change., B. People's views remain unchanged., C. People become more likely to accept the reality of climate change., D. The outcome is not specified in the transcript. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main point of the transcript regarding the importance of understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us? Options: A. It is not important to understand what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us., B. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is a simple process., C. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is crucial for making convincing arguments., D. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is not a key factor in making convincing arguments. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Question 3: What was the outcome of a 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan and Jason Reifler regarding American attitudes towards the Iraq War?**

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Three people are at a dinner party. Paul, who’s married, is looking at Linda. Meanwhile, Linda is looking at John, 
who’s not married. Is someone who’s married looking 
at someone who’s not married? Take a moment to think about it. Most people answer that there’s 
not enough information to tell. And most people are wrong. Linda must be either married 
or not married—there are no other options. So in either scenario, someone married 
is looking at someone who’s not married. When presented with the explanation, 
most people change their minds and accept the correct answer, despite being very confident 
in their first responses. Now let’s look at another case. A 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan 
and Jason Reifler examined American attitudes regarding 
the justifications for the Iraq War. Researchers presented participants 
with a news article that showed no weapons 
of mass destruction had been found. Yet many participants not only continued 
to believe that WMDs had been found, but they even became more convinced 
of their original views. So why do arguments change people’s minds 
in some cases and backfire in others? Arguments are more convincing when they 
rest on a good knowledge of the audience, taking into account 
what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value. Mathematical and logical arguments 
like the dinner party brainteaser work because even when people 
reach different conclusions, they’re starting from 
the same set of shared beliefs. In 1931, a young, unknown mathematician 
named Kurt Gödel presented a proof that a logically complete
system of mathematics was impossible. Despite upending decades of
work by brilliant mathematicians like Bertrand Russell and David Hilbert, the proof was accepted because it relied on axioms that 
everyone in the field already agreed on. Of course, many disagreements involve 
different beliefs that can’t simply be reconciled
through logic. When these beliefs involve 
outside information, the issue often comes down to
what sources and authorities people trust. One study asked people to estimate 
several statistics related to the scope of climate change. Participants were asked questions, such as “how many of the years 
between 1995 and 2006 were one of the hottest 12 years 
since 1850?” After providing their answers, they were presented with data from the
Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, in this case showing that the answer 
was 11 of the 12 years. Being provided with these reliable 
statistics from a trusted official source made people more likely to accept 
the reality that the earth is warming. Finally, for disagreements that 
can’t be definitively settled with statistics or evidence, making a convincing argument may depend on engaging 
the audience’s values. For example, researchers have conducted 
a number of studies where they’ve asked people 
of different political backgrounds to rank their values. Liberals in these studies, 
on average, rank fairness— here meaning whether everyone is treated 
in the same way—above loyalty. In later studies, researchers attempted 
to convince liberals to support military spending with 
a variety of arguments. Arguments based on fairness— like that the military provides employment and education to people 
from disadvantaged backgrounds— were more convincing than arguments 
based on loyalty— such as that the military 
unifies a nation. These three elements— beliefs, trusted sources, and values— may seem like a simple formula 
for finding agreement and consensus. The problem is that our initial 
inclination is to think of arguments that rely on our own beliefs, 
trusted sources, and values. And even when we don’t, it can be challenging to correctly 
identify what’s held dear by people who don’t already agree with us. The best way to find out
is simply to talk to them. In the course of discussion, you’ll be exposed to counter-arguments
and rebuttals. These can help you make your own 
arguments and reasoning more convincing and sometimes, you may even end up 
being the one changing your mind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why are mathematical arguments more likely to change people’s minds?
Options: A. They start from the same set of shared beliefs, B. They are entertaining and easy to understand, C. They confuse people, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the outcome when most people are presented with the explanation of the dinner party scenario? Options: A. They still disagree with the correct answer., B. They become even more confident in their original views., C. They change their minds and accept the correct answer., D. They are unable to make a decision. Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why arguments based on mathematical and logical reasoning are effective? Options: A. They appeal to people's emotions., B. They rely on a good knowledge of the audience's values., C. They rely on a good knowledge of the audience's beliefs., D. They are presented in a visually appealing format. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the outcome of a 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan and Jason Reifler regarding American attitudes towards the Iraq War? Options: A. Participants became less convinced of their original views., B. Participants' views remained unchanged., C. Participants became more convinced of their original views., D. The study found no correlation between views and arguments. Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the key to making a convincing argument when dealing with disagreements that involve different beliefs? Options: A. Appealing to people's emotions., B. Relying on a good knowledge of the audience's values., C. Presenting evidence from trusted sources., D. Using logical reasoning. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the main difference between liberals and conservatives in terms of their values, according to the transcript? Options: A. Liberals prioritize loyalty over fairness, while conservatives prioritize fairness over loyalty., B. Liberals prioritize fairness over loyalty, while conservatives prioritize loyalty over fairness., C. Liberals and conservatives have the same values., D. The difference is not specified in the transcript. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the best way to find out what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us, according to the transcript? Options: A. By reading their written opinions., B. By engaging in online discussions., C. By talking to them directly., D. By analyzing their social media profiles. Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of being exposed to counter-arguments and rebuttals in the course of discussion? Options: A. We become more entrenched in our original views., B. We are unable to change our minds., C. We make our own arguments and reasoning more convincing., D. We become less confident in our opinions. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary reason why Kurt Gödel's proof was accepted by mathematicians in 1931? Options: A. It relied on axioms that everyone in the field already agreed on., B. It was presented in a visually appealing format., C. It appealed to people's emotions., D. It was based on personal opinions. Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of being provided with reliable statistics from a trusted official source, such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change? Options: A. People become less likely to accept the reality of climate change., B. People's views remain unchanged., C. People become more likely to accept the reality of climate change., D. The outcome is not specified in the transcript. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main point of the transcript regarding the importance of understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us? Options: A. It is not important to understand what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us., B. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is a simple process., C. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is crucial for making convincing arguments., D. Understanding what values are held dear by people who don't already agree with us is not a key factor in making convincing arguments. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Here's why:

- Both the ground truth MCQ and Question 2 focus on the effectiveness of mathematical and logical arguments.
- The correct options for both questions (A for the ground truth MCQ and C for Question 2) convey the same idea: mathematical and logical arguments are effective because they rely on shared beliefs or a good understanding of the audience's beliefs.
- The question intent and content are similar, as both questions aim to assess the understanding of why mathematical and logical arguments can be persuasive.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Three people are at a dinner party. Paul, who’s married, is looking at Linda. Meanwhile, Linda is looking at John, 
who’s not married. Is someone who’s married looking 
at someone who’s not married? Take a moment to think about it. Most people answer that there’s 
not enough information to tell. And most people are wrong. Linda must be either married 
or not married—there are no other options. So in either scenario, someone married 
is looking at someone who’s not married. When presented with the explanation, 
most people change their minds and accept the correct answer, despite being very confident 
in their first responses. Now let’s look at another case. A 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan 
and Jason Reifler examined American attitudes regarding 
the justifications for the Iraq War. Researchers presented participants 
with a news article that showed no weapons 
of mass destruction had been found. Yet many participants not only continued 
to believe that WMDs had been found, but they even became more convinced 
of their original views. So why do arguments change people’s minds 
in some cases and backfire in others? Arguments are more convincing when they 
rest on a good knowledge of the audience, taking into account 
what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value. Mathematical and logical arguments 
like the dinner party brainteaser work because even when people 
reach different conclusions, they’re starting from 
the same set of shared beliefs. In 1931, a young, unknown mathematician 
named Kurt Gödel presented a proof that a logically complete
system of mathematics was impossible. Despite upending decades of
work by brilliant mathematicians like Bertrand Russell and David Hilbert, the proof was accepted because it relied on axioms that 
everyone in the field already agreed on. Of course, many disagreements involve 
different beliefs that can’t simply be reconciled
through logic. When these beliefs involve 
outside information, the issue often comes down to
what sources and authorities people trust. One study asked people to estimate 
several statistics related to the scope of climate change. Participants were asked questions, such as “how many of the years 
between 1995 and 2006 were one of the hottest 12 years

was 11 of the 12 years. Being provided with these reliable 
statistics from a trusted official source made people more likely to accept 
the reality that the earth is warming. Finally, for disagreements that 
can’t be definitively settled with statistics or evidence, making a convincing argument may depend on engaging 
the audience’s values. For example, researchers have conducted 
a number of studies where they’ve asked people 
of different political backgrounds to rank their values. Liberals in these studies, 
on average, rank fairness— here meaning whether everyone is treated 
in the same way—above loyalty. In later studies, researchers attempted 
to convince liberals to support military spending with 
a variety of arguments. Arguments based on fairness— like that the military provides employment and education to people 
from disadvantaged backgrounds— were more convincing than arguments

unifies a nation. These three elements— beliefs, trusted sources, and values— may seem like a simple formula 
for finding agreement and consensus. The problem is that our initial

trusted sources, and values. And even when we don’t, it can be challenging to correctly 
identify what’s held dear by people who don’t already agree with us. The best way to find out
is simply to talk to them. In the course of discussion, you’ll be exposed to counter-arguments
and rebuttals. These can help you make your own 
arguments and reasoning more convincing and sometimes, you may even end up 
being the one changing your mind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why are arguments a worthy form of debate?
Options: A. Arguments should be avoided at all costs, B. They expose you to counterarguments, which help make your own arguments and reasoning more convincing—and sometimes change your mind, C. They allow you to yell at someone, D. They are only worthy if the other person agrees with you
Correct Option: B

- Options: While the options are not identical, they convey similar ideas. The correct option in the ground truth MCQ (B) mentions that arguments expose you to counterarguments, which help make your own arguments and reasoning more convincing—and sometimes change your mind. Similarly, the correct option in Question 7 (C) states that being exposed to counterarguments and rebuttals helps make your own arguments and reasoning more convincing.
- Content: Both questions relate to the idea that engaging with opposing views can lead to personal growth and improvement in one's argumentation skills.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s another sweltering morning 
in Memphis, Egypt. As the sunlight brightens the Nile, 
Peseshet checks her supplies. Honey, garlic, cumin, acacia leaves, cedar oil. She’s well stocked with the essentials 
she needs to treat her patients. Peseshet is a swnw, or a doctor. In order to become one, she had to train as a scribe and study the medical papyri stored 
at the Per Ankh, the House of Life. Now, she teaches her own students there. Before teaching, 
Peseshet has a patient to see. One of the workers at the temple 
construction site has injured his arm. When Peseshet arrives, the laborer’s arm is clearly broken, and worse, the fracture is a sed, 
with multiple bone fragments. Peseshet binds and immobilizes the injury. Her next stop is the House of Life. On her way, a woman intercepts 
Peseshet in the street. The woman’s son 
has been stung by a scorpion. Peseshet has seen many similar stings 
and knows exactly what to do. She must say an incantation 
to cast the poison out. She begins to recite the spell, invoking Serqet, patron of physicians 
and goddess of venomous creatures. Peseshet recites the spell 
as if she is Serqet. This commanding approach 
has the greatest chance at success. After she utters the last line, she tries to cut the poison out 
with a knife for good measure. Peseshet packs up to leave,
but the woman has another question. She wants to find out if she is pregnant. Peseshet explains 
her fail-safe pregnancy test: plant two seeds: one barley, one emmer. Then, urinate on the seeds every day. If the plants grow, she’s pregnant. A barley seedling predicts a baby boy, while emmer foretells a girl. Peseshet also recommends a prayer
to Hathor, goddess of fertility. When Peseshet finally arrives 
at the House of Life, she runs into the doctor-priest Isesi. She greets Isesi politely, but she thinks
priests are very full of themselves. She doesn’t envy Isesi’s role 
as neru pehut, which directly translates to herdsman 
of the anus to the royal family, or, guardian of the royal anus. Inside, the House of Life is bustling 
as usual with scribes, priests, doctors, and students. Papyri containing all kinds of records, 
not just medical information, are stored here. Peseshet’s son Akhethetep is hard 
at work copying documents as part of his training 
to become a scribe. He’s a particularly promising student, but he was admitted to study 
because Peseshet is a scribe, as was her father before her. Without family in the profession, it’s very difficult for boys, 
and impossible for girls, to pursue this education. Peseshet oversees all the female 
swnws and swnws-in-training in Memphis. The men have their own overseer, as the male doctors 
won’t answer to a woman. Today, Peseshet teaches anatomy. She quizzes her students on the metu, the body’s vessels that transport blood, air, urine, and even bad spirits. Peseshet is preparing to leave when a pale, thin woman accosts her 
at the door and begs to be examined. The woman has a huge, 
sore lump under her arm. Peseshet probes the growth 
and finds it cool to the touch and hard like an unripe hemat fruit. She has read about ailments 
like this, but never seen one. For this tumor there is no treatment, 
medicine or spell. All the texts give the same advice: 
do nothing. After delivering the bad news, 
Peseshet goes outside. She lingers on the steps
of the House of Life, admiring the city at dusk. In spite of all her hard work, there will always be patients 
she can’t help, like the woman with the tumor. They linger with her,
but Peseshet has no time to dwell. In a few short weeks, the Nile’s annual flooding will begin, bringing life to the soil for 
the next year’s harvest and a whole new crop of patients.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is the patron god or goddess of physicians?
Options: A. Hathor, B. Osiris, C. Anubis, D. Serqet
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the doctor in the transcript? Options: A. Isesi, B. Akhethetep, C. Serqet, D. Peseshet Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the name of the goddess associated with venomous creatures? Options: A. Serqet, B. B: Hathor, C. Per Ankh, D. Metu Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the name of the prayer that Peseshet recommends to the woman who wants to find out if she is pregnant? Options: A. Prayer to Serqet, B. Prayer to Hathor, C. Prayer to the Nile, D. Prayer to Per Ankh Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the purpose of the fail-safe pregnancy test described in the transcript? Options: A. To determine the sex of the baby, B. To determine if the woman is pregnant, C. To determine the due date of the baby, D. To determine the weight of the baby Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the role of the neru pehut in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Herdsman of the anus to the royal family, B. Guardian of the royal anus, C. Doctor to the royal family, D. Scribe to the royal family Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the medical text that Peseshet read about the tumor under the woman's arm? Options: A. The Metu, B. The Per Ankh, C. The medical papyri, D. The House of Life Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the treatment for the tumor under the woman's arm? Options: A. Medicine, B. Spell, C. Do nothing, D. Surgery Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of the Nile's annual flooding in the transcript? Options: A. It brings life to the soil for the next year's harvest, B. It brings death to the people of Memphis, C. It brings disease to the people of Memphis, D. It brings poverty to the people of Memphis Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, why Peseshet's son Akhethetep was admitted to study as a scribe? Options: A. Because he is a promising student, B. Because his father is a scribe, C. Because his mother is a scribe, D. Because his family has a long history of being scribes Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the reason why it is difficult for boys and impossible for girls to pursue education as scribes in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Because they are not intelligent enough, B. Because they do not have the financial resources, C. Because it is a male-dominated profession, D. Because they do not have family in the profession Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the name of the body's vessels that transport blood, air, urine, and even bad spirits? Options: A. The Metu, B. The Per Ankh, C. The medical papyri, D. The House of Life Correct Option: A
Question 12: According to the transcript, what is the name of the location where Peseshet teaches her students? Options: A. The House of Life, B. The Temple of Per Ankh, C. The Temple of Serqet, D. The Temple of Hathor Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the reason why Peseshet has no time to dwell on the patients she can't help? Options: A. Because she has to attend to her family, B. Because she has to attend to her patients, C. Because the Nile's annual flooding will begin soon, D. Because she has to teach her students Correct Option: C
Question 14: According to the transcript, what is the occupation of Peseshet's son Akhethetep? Options: A. Scribe, B. Doctor, C. Priest, D. Soldier Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the name of the goddess associated with fertility? Options: A. Serqet, B. Hathor, C. Per Ankh, D. Metu Correct Option: B
Question 16: What is the occupation of Peseshet in the transcript? Options: A. Scribe, B. Doctor, C. Priest, D. Soldier Correct Option: B
Question 17: According to the transcript, what is the treatment for the scorpion sting? Options: A. Medicine, B. Spell, C. Do nothing, D. Surgery Correct Option: B
Question 18: What is the significance of the House of Life in the transcript? Options: A. It is a temple dedicated to Serqet, B. It is a school for scribes, C. It is a location where doctors and scribes work together, D. It is a place where medical texts are stored Correct Option: D
Question 19: What is the reason why Peseshet thinks priests are full of themselves? Options: A. Because they are arrogant, B. Because they are knowledgeable, C. Because they have a lot of power, D. Because they have a lot of responsibility Correct Option: A
Question 20: According to the transcript, what is the occupation of Isesi? Options: A. Scribe, B. Doctor, C. Priest, D. Soldier Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the name of the goddess associated with venomous creatures? Options: A. Serqet, B. Hathor, C. Per Ankh, D. Metu Correct Option: A**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the patron god or goddess of physicians/venomous creatures, and both have Serqet as the correct answer.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **2**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s another sweltering morning 
in Memphis, Egypt. As the sunlight brightens the Nile, 
Peseshet checks her supplies. Honey, garlic, cumin, acacia leaves, cedar oil. She’s well stocked with the essentials 
she needs to treat her patients. Peseshet is a swnw, or a doctor. In order to become one, she had to train as a scribe and study the medical papyri stored

Peseshet in the street. The woman’s son 
has been stung by a scorpion. Peseshet has seen many similar stings 
and knows exactly what to do. She must say an incantation 
to cast the poison out. She begins to recite the spell, invoking Serqet, patron of physicians 
and goddess of venomous creatures. Peseshet recites the spell 
as if she is Serqet. This commanding approach 
has the greatest chance at success. After she utters the last line, she tries to cut the poison out 
with a knife for good measure. Peseshet packs up to leave,
but the woman has another question. She wants to find out if she is pregnant. Peseshet explains 
her fail-safe pregnancy test: plant two seeds: one barley, one emmer. Then, urinate on the seeds every day. If the plants grow, she’s pregnant. A barley seedling predicts a baby boy, while emmer foretells a girl. Peseshet also recommends a prayer
to Hathor, goddess of fertility. When Peseshet finally arrives 
at the House of Life, she runs into the doctor-priest Isesi. She greets Isesi politely, but she thinks
priests are very full of themselves. She doesn’t envy Isesi’s role 
as neru pehut, which directly translates to herdsman 
of the anus to the royal family, or, guardian of the royal anus. Inside, the House of Life is bustling 
as usual with scribes, priests, doctors, and students. Papyri containing all kinds of records, 
not just medical information, are stored here. Peseshet’s son Akhethetep is hard 
at work copying documents as part of his training 
to become a scribe. He’s a particularly promising student, but he was admitted to study 
because Peseshet is a scribe, as was her father before her. Without family in the profession, it’s very difficult for boys, 
and impossible for girls, to pursue this education. Peseshet oversees all the female 
swnws and swnws-in-training in Memphis. The men have their own overseer, as the male doctors 
won’t answer to a woman. Today, Peseshet teaches anatomy. She quizzes her students on the metu, the body’s vessels that transport blood, air, urine, and even bad spirits. Peseshet is preparing to leave when a pale, thin woman accosts her 
at the door and begs to be examined. The woman has a huge, 
sore lump under her arm. Peseshet probes the growth 
and finds it cool to the touch and hard like an unripe hemat fruit. She has read about ailments 
like this, but never seen one. For this tumor there is no treatment, 
medicine or spell. All the texts give the same advice: 
do nothing. After delivering the bad news, 
Peseshet goes outside. She lingers on the steps
of the House of Life, admiring the city at dusk. In spite of all her hard work, there will always be patients 
she can’t help, like the woman with the tumor. They linger with her,
but Peseshet has no time to dwell. In a few short weeks, the Nile’s annual flooding will begin, bringing life to the soil for 
the next year’s harvest and a whole new crop of patients.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to the ancient Egyptians, how did blood travel around the body?
Options: A. In the metu, B. By magic, C. In vessels called swnws, D. It didn't
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the doctor in the transcript? Options: A. Isesi, B. Akhethetep, C. Serqet, D. Peseshet Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the name of the goddess associated with venomous creatures? Options: A. Serqet, B. B: Hathor, C. Per Ankh, D. Metu Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the name of the prayer that Peseshet recommends to the woman who wants to find out if she is pregnant? Options: A. Prayer to Serqet, B. Prayer to Hathor, C. Prayer to the Nile, D. Prayer to Per Ankh Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the purpose of the fail-safe pregnancy test described in the transcript? Options: A. To determine the sex of the baby, B. To determine if the woman is pregnant, C. To determine the due date of the baby, D. To determine the weight of the baby Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the role of the neru pehut in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Herdsman of the anus to the royal family, B. Guardian of the royal anus, C. Doctor to the royal family, D. Scribe to the royal family Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the medical text that Peseshet read about the tumor under the woman's arm? Options: A. The Metu, B. The Per Ankh, C. The medical papyri, D. The House of Life Correct Option: C

It brings death to the people of Memphis, C. It brings disease to the people of Memphis, D. It brings poverty to the people of Memphis Correct Option: A

Question 10: What is the reason why it is difficult for boys and impossible for girls to pursue education as scribes in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Because they are not intelligent enough, B. Because they do not have the financial resources, C. Because it is a male-dominated profession, D. Because they do not have family in the profession Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the name of the body's vessels that transport blood, air, urine, and even bad spirits? Options: A. The Metu, B. The Per Ankh, C. The medical papyri, D. The House of Life Correct Option: A
Question 12: According to the transcript, what is the name of the location where Peseshet teaches her students? Options: A. The House of Life, B. The Temple of Per Ankh, C. The Temple of Serqet, D. The Temple of Hathor Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the reason why Peseshet has no time to dwell on the patients she can't help? Options: A. Because she has to attend to her family, B. Because she has to attend to her patients, C. Because the Nile's annual flooding will begin soon, D. Because she has to teach her students Correct Option: C
Question 14: According to the transcript, what is the occupation of Peseshet's son Akhethetep? Options: A. Scribe, B. Doctor, C. Priest, D. Soldier Correct Option: A

Question 17: According to the transcript, what is the treatment for the scorpion sting? Options: A. Medicine, B. Spell, C. Do nothing, D. Surgery Correct Option: B
Question 18: What is the significance of the House of Life in the transcript? Options: A. It is a temple dedicated to Serqet, B. It is a school for scribes, C. It is a location where doctors and scribes work together, D. It is a place where medical texts are stored Correct Option: D
Question 19: What is the reason why Peseshet thinks priests are full of themselves? Options: A. Because they are arrogant, B. Because they are knowledgeable, C. Because they have a lot of power, D. Because they have a lot of responsibility Correct Option: A
Question 20: According to the transcript, what is the occupation of Isesi? Options: A. Scribe, B. Doctor, C. Priest, D. Soldier Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s another sweltering morning 
in Memphis, Egypt. As the sunlight brightens the Nile, 
Peseshet checks her supplies. Honey, garlic, cumin, acacia leaves, cedar oil. She’s well stocked with the essentials 
she needs to treat her patients. Peseshet is a swnw, or a doctor. In order to become one, she had to train as a scribe and study the medical papyri stored 
at the Per Ankh, the House of Life. Now, she teaches her own students there. Before teaching, 
Peseshet has a patient to see. One of the workers at the temple 
construction site has injured his arm. When Peseshet arrives, the laborer’s arm is clearly broken, and worse, the fracture is a sed, 
with multiple bone fragments. Peseshet binds and immobilizes the injury. Her next stop is the House of Life. On her way, a woman intercepts 
Peseshet in the street. The woman’s son 
has been stung by a scorpion. Peseshet has seen many similar stings 
and knows exactly what to do. She must say an incantation 
to cast the poison out. She begins to recite the spell, invoking Serqet, patron of physicians 
and goddess of venomous creatures. Peseshet recites the spell 
as if she is Serqet. This commanding approach 
has the greatest chance at success. After she utters the last line, she tries to cut the poison out 
with a knife for good measure. Peseshet packs up to leave,
but the woman has another question. She wants to find out if she is pregnant. Peseshet explains 
her fail-safe pregnancy test: plant two seeds: one barley, one emmer. Then, urinate on the seeds every day. If the plants grow, she’s pregnant. A barley seedling predicts a baby boy, while emmer foretells a girl. Peseshet also recommends a prayer
to Hathor, goddess of fertility. When Peseshet finally arrives 
at the House of Life, she runs into the doctor-priest Isesi. She greets Isesi politely, but she thinks
priests are very full of themselves. She doesn’t envy Isesi’s role 
as neru pehut, which directly translates to herdsman 
of the anus to the royal family, or, guardian of the royal anus. Inside, the House of Life is bustling 
as usual with scribes, priests, doctors, and students. Papyri containing all kinds of records, 
not just medical information, are stored here. Peseshet’s son Akhethetep is hard 
at work copying documents as part of his training 
to become a scribe. He’s a particularly promising student, but he was admitted to study 
because Peseshet is a scribe, as was her father before her. Without family in the profession, it’s very difficult for boys, 
and impossible for girls, to pursue this education. Peseshet oversees all the female 
swnws and swnws-in-training in Memphis. The men have their own overseer, as the male doctors 
won’t answer to a woman. Today, Peseshet teaches anatomy. She quizzes her students on the metu, the body’s vessels that transport blood, air, urine, and even bad spirits. Peseshet is preparing to leave when a pale, thin woman accosts her 
at the door and begs to be examined. The woman has a huge, 
sore lump under her arm. Peseshet probes the growth 
and finds it cool to the touch and hard like an unripe hemat fruit. She has read about ailments 
like this, but never seen one. For this tumor there is no treatment, 
medicine or spell. All the texts give the same advice: 
do nothing. After delivering the bad news, 
Peseshet goes outside. She lingers on the steps
of the House of Life, admiring the city at dusk. In spite of all her hard work, there will always be patients 
she can’t help, like the woman with the tumor. They linger with her,
but Peseshet has no time to dwell. In a few short weeks, the Nile’s annual flooding will begin, bringing life to the soil for 
the next year’s harvest and a whole new crop of patients.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the papyri advise doctors to do to treat a tumor?
Options: A. Cast spells, B. Perform surgery, C. Administer medication, D. Cast spells and perform surgery, E. Do nothing
Correct Option: E
