Question 2: What is another name for ALS? Options: A. Motor Neuron Disease, B. Lou Gehrig’s Disease, C. Parkinson’s Disease, D. Alzheimer’s Disease Correct Option: A
Question 3: Approximately how many people are diagnosed with ALS annually? Options: A. 100,000, B. 120,000, C. 150,000, D. 200,000 Correct Option: B
Question 4: What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary? Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 90%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 5: At what age do ALS symptoms typically first appear? Options: A. Before age 20, B. Between age 20 and 40, C. After age 40, D. After age 60 Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the primary cause of death in ALS patients? Options: A. Respiratory problems, B. Heart disease, C. Cancer, D. Stroke Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the primary function of upper motor neurons? Options: A. To transmit messages from the muscles to the brain, B. To transmit messages from the brain to the spinal cord, C. To transmit messages from the brain to the lower motor neurons, D. To transmit messages from the spinal cord to the muscles Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one prevailing idea about the causes of ALS? Options: A. Certain toxins cause the disease, B. Misfolded proteins and clumps inside motor neurons may be responsible, C. Genetic mutations are the sole cause of ALS, D. Inflammation in the brain and spinal cord is the primary cause Correct Option: B
Question 9: What types of treatments are being developed for ALS? Options: A. Gene therapy to repair damaged cells, B. Gene therapy to slow the advancement of the disease, C. Vaccination, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of ALS research, according to the transcript? Options: A. To understand the causes of ALS, B. To develop new treatments for ALS, C. To cure ALS, D. To increase awareness about ALS Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the approximate lifespan of a person with ALS after diagnosis, according to the transcript? Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 10-15 years Correct Option: B
Question 12: What may be responsible for the degeneration of motor neurons in ALS? Options: A. Genetic mutations, B. Toxins, C. Misfolded proteins and clumps, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After months of travel, 
you’ve arrived at Duonia, home to the famous temple that’s 
the destination of your pilgrimage. Entering from the northwest, you pass through the city gates 
and the welcome center, where you’re given a map and a brochure. The map reveals that the town consists
of 16 blocks, formed by five streets that 
run west to east, intersecting five more 
that run north to south. You’re standing on the
northernmost street facing east, with the two blocks containing the gate 
and the welcome center behind you. The temple’s only entrance lies 
at the very southeast corner. It’s not a long walk, 
but there’s a problem. As you learn from the brochure, Duonia imposes a unique tax 
on all visitors, which must be paid when they arrive 
at their destination within the city. The tax begins at zero, increases by two silver 
for every block you walk east, and doubles for every block 
you walk south. However, a recent reform 
to make the tax fairer halves your total bill for
every block you walk north and subtracts two silver 
for every block you walk west. Just passing through the gate 
and the welcome center means you already owe four silver. As a pilgrim you carry no money 
and have no way of earning any. What’s more, the rules 
of your pilgrimage forbid you from walking over any stretch of
ground more than once during your journey— though you can cross your own path. Can you figure out a way to reach 
the temple without owing any tax or walking the same block twice 
in any direction? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 You look at the map 
to consider your options. Walking towards the temple 
always increases the tax, and walking away decreases it, so it seems like you can never reach it
without owing silver. But what happens when you walk 
around a single block? If you start out owing four silver
and go clockwise starting east, your tax bill becomes six, then 12, then 10, then five. If you looped again, you’d owe seven, 14, 12, and six. It seems that each clockwise loop leaves 
you owing one extra silver. What about a counterclockwise loop then? Starting owing four again 
and going south first, your bill changes to eight, 10, five, and three. Looping again you’d owe six, eight, four, and two. Each counterclockwise loop actually earns 
you one silver. That’s because any tax doubled, plus two, halved, and minus two, always ends up one smaller 
than it started. The key here is that while the different 
taxes for opposite directions may seem to balance each other out, the order in which they’re applied 
makes a huge difference. You start off owing four silver, so four counterclockwise loops would 
get you down to zero. Unfortunately, it’s not that simple, 
since you can’t walk the same block twice. But there’s another way
to reduce your bill: walking one large counterclockwise loop
through the city. From your starting position, 
walk three blocks south. You need to leave the southernmost 
street clear for the final stretch, so continuing counterclockwise 
means going east. Walk two blocks to the eastern wall 
and you owe a whopping 36 silver. But now you can start reducing your bill. Three blocks north and one block west 
cuts it to 2.5. You can’t go west from here 
—that would leave you with no way out. So you go one block south, 
and the remaining three blocks west, leaving you with a debt 
of -1 silver. And since doubling a negative number 
still gives you a negative number, walking the three blocks to the south wall
means the city owes you eight. Fortunately, that’s exactly enough to get you through the final blocks 
to the temple. As you enter, you realize what 
you’ve learned from your pilgrimage: sometimes an indirect route 
is the best way to reach your destination.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If the pilgrim traveled east, east, south, south, south, south to reach the temple, what would his tax be?
Options: A. 100, B. 64, C. 128, D. 256
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary objective of the New Horizons spacecraft mission? Options: A. To study the Kuiper Belt and its objects, B. To conduct a flyby mission of Pluto and collect scientific data, C. To establish a permanent human settlement on Pluto, D. To explore the outer reaches of the solar system Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the approximate distance between Pluto and Earth when New Horizons was about to fly by? Options: A. 1 billion kilometers, B. 5 billion kilometers, C. 10 billion kilometers, D. 20 billion kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the term used to describe the gravitational effect experienced by the New Horizons spacecraft when it flew close to Jupiter? Options: A. Gravity boost, B. Orbital assist, C. Solar slingshot, D. Gravity assist Correct Option: D
Question 4: Why was the New Horizons spacecraft on a flyby mission to Pluto? Options: A. Because it was too heavy to land on Pluto's surface, B. Because it was too far away from Earth to receive signals, C. Because it was designed to collect as much scientific data as possible in a short time, D. Because it was running out of fuel Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the main challenge faced by the New Horizons team when trying to get the spacecraft to Pluto in time? Options: A. The spacecraft was too slow, B. Pluto's atmosphere was freezing due to its orbit, C. The spacecraft was experiencing technical difficulties, D. The spacecraft was too heavy Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the outcome of the New Horizons mission to Pluto? Options: A. The spacecraft failed to collect any scientific data, B. The spacecraft collected limited scientific data, C. The spacecraft collected breathtaking images and revealed a delightfully varied world, D. The spacecraft did not reach Pluto Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the glacier discovered by the New Horizons spacecraft on Pluto? Options: A. Sputnik Planitia glacier, B. Pluto Glacier, C. New Horizons Glacier, D. Kuiper Belt Glacier Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the next destination of the New Horizons spacecraft after its successful mission to Pluto? Options: A. A Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69, B. A planet in the solar system, C. A comet in the solar system, D. A star in the galaxy Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the role of Alice Bowman, the mission's Operations Manager, in getting the New Horizons spacecraft back on track? Options: A. She was responsible for loading the spacecraft with scientific instruments, B. She was responsible for designing the spacecraft's trajectory, C. She led a team for 72 sleepless hours to get the instructions loaded back into the spacecraft in time, D. She was responsible for conducting the flyby mission Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the New Horizons mission to the scientific community? Options: A. It was the first mission to explore the Kuiper Belt, B. It was the first mission to study the atmosphere of Pluto, C. It revealed a delightfully varied world and made several groundbreaking discoveries, D. It did not make any significant discoveries Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Question 8: What is the next destination of the New Horizons spacecraft after its successful mission to Pluto? Options: A. A Kuiper Belt Object called 2014 MU69, B. A planet in the solar system, C. A comet in the solar system, D. A star in the galaxy Correct Option: A

She was responsible for loading the spacecraft with scientific instruments, B. She was responsible for designing the spacecraft's trajectory, C. She led a team for 72 sleepless hours to get the instructions loaded back into the spacecraft in time, D. She was responsible for conducting the flyby mission Correct Option: C

It was the first mission to study the atmosphere of Pluto, C. It revealed a delightfully varied world and made several groundbreaking discoveries, D. It did not make any significant discoveries Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After months of travel, 
you’ve arrived at Duonia, home to the famous temple that’s 
the destination of your pilgrimage. Entering from the northwest, you pass through the city gates 
and the welcome center, where you’re given a map and a brochure. The map reveals that the town consists
of 16 blocks, formed by five streets that 
run west to east, intersecting five more 
that run north to south. You’re standing on the
northernmost street facing east, with the two blocks containing the gate 
and the welcome center behind you. The temple’s only entrance lies 
at the very southeast corner. It’s not a long walk, 
but there’s a problem. As you learn from the brochure, Duonia imposes a unique tax 
on all visitors, which must be paid when they arrive 
at their destination within the city. The tax begins at zero, increases by two silver 
for every block you walk east, and doubles for every block 
you walk south. However, a recent reform 
to make the tax fairer halves your total bill for
every block you walk north and subtracts two silver 
for every block you walk west. Just passing through the gate 
and the welcome center means you already owe four silver. As a pilgrim you carry no money 
and have no way of earning any. What’s more, the rules 
of your pilgrimage forbid you from walking over any stretch of
ground more than once during your journey— though you can cross your own path. Can you figure out a way to reach 
the temple without owing any tax or walking the same block twice 
in any direction? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 You look at the map 
to consider your options. Walking towards the temple 
always increases the tax, and walking away decreases it, so it seems like you can never reach it
without owing silver. But what happens when you walk 
around a single block? If you start out owing four silver
and go clockwise starting east, your tax bill becomes six, then 12, then 10, then five. If you looped again, you’d owe seven, 14, 12, and six. It seems that each clockwise loop leaves 
you owing one extra silver. What about a counterclockwise loop then? Starting owing four again 
and going south first, your bill changes to eight, 10, five, and three. Looping again you’d owe six, eight, four, and two. Each counterclockwise loop actually earns 
you one silver. That’s because any tax doubled, plus two, halved, and minus two, always ends up one smaller 
than it started. The key here is that while the different 
taxes for opposite directions may seem to balance each other out, the order in which they’re applied 
makes a huge difference. You start off owing four silver, so four counterclockwise loops would 
get you down to zero. Unfortunately, it’s not that simple, 
since you can’t walk the same block twice. But there’s another way
to reduce your bill: walking one large counterclockwise loop
through the city. From your starting position, 
walk three blocks south. You need to leave the southernmost 
street clear for the final stretch, so continuing counterclockwise 
means going east. Walk two blocks to the eastern wall 
and you owe a whopping 36 silver. But now you can start reducing your bill. Three blocks north and one block west 
cuts it to 2.5. You can’t go west from here 
—that would leave you with no way out. So you go one block south, 
and the remaining three blocks west, leaving you with a debt 
of -1 silver. And since doubling a negative number 
still gives you a negative number, walking the three blocks to the south wall
means the city owes you eight. Fortunately, that’s exactly enough to get you through the final blocks 
to the temple. As you enter, you realize what 
you’ve learned from your pilgrimage: sometimes an indirect route 
is the best way to reach your destination.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If the pilgrim looped back to where she started, she would owe the same tax.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

Warning: No valid match index found in response for Ground Truth Set 18, Question 6
Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is also called _______.
Options: A. Multiple sclerosis, B. Motor neuron disease, C. Lou Gehrig’s disease, D. Motor neuron disease and Lou Gehrig's disease
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of the mitochondria in cells during exercise? Options: A. To produce ATP, the energy currency of the cell, which is then broken down to release heat and stimulate sweating., B. To regulate body temperature directly., C. To break down glucose and oxygen, but not to produce ATP., D. To increase muscle activity without producing energy. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What process takes place in the sweat gland to prepare the primary secretion for evaporation? Options: A. Osmosis, where water moves into the tube by osmosis, driven by the higher concentration of ions inside the tube., B. Diffusion, where salt is released into the sweat., C. Respiration, where glucose and oxygen are consumed in the mitochondria., D. Filtration, where excess water is removed from the sweat. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What happens to the body's temperature when sweat evaporates from the skin? Options: A. It increases due to the heat energy released from the sweat., B. It remains the same, as the sweat is just a byproduct of exercise., C. It decreases due to the cooling effect of evaporation., D. It becomes unstable, leading to fluctuations in body temperature. Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does the hypothalamus regulate body temperature in response to excessive heat? Options: A. By detecting the excess heat produced by muscle cells and responding with sweating., B. By sending signals to the sweat glands to produce more sweat., C. By stimulating the sympathetic nervous system to increase muscle activity., D. By reducing muscle activity to decrease heat production. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the role of the sympathetic nervous system in the sweating response? Options: A. To stimulate the sweat glands to produce more sweat in response to signals from the hypothalamus., B. To reduce muscle activity and decrease heat production., C. To detect the excess heat produced by muscle cells and respond with sweating., D. To increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels, leading to increased heat and sweating. Correct Option: A
Question 6: In what ways does the body's sweating response help to protect against infections? Options: A. By increasing the body's temperature, making it less habitable for infectious agents., B. By decreasing the body's temperature, making it more habitable for infectious agents., C. By increasing muscle activity, leading to increased heat production., D. By reducing sweat production, leading to decreased heat loss. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the relationship between the hypothalamus and the sweat glands in regulating body temperature? Options: A. The hypothalamus detects excess heat and responds with sweating by stimulating the sweat glands., B. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature by increasing muscle activity., C. The hypothalamus and sweat glands work together to maintain a stable body temperature through sweating., D. The hypothalamus and sweat glands are separate systems that do not interact. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the body's sweating response to exercise help to replenish water lost during exercise? Options: A. By signaling the body to replenish water lost through the hypothalamus., B. By increasing water intake, leading to increased sweat production., C. By reducing sweat production, leading to decreased water loss., D. By increasing muscle activity, leading to increased water consumption. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the significance of sweating in the fight or flight response? Options: A. It helps to increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels, leading to increased heat and sweating., B. It has no role in the fight or flight response., C. It helps to decrease muscle activity and decrease heat production., D. It helps to increase heart rate and blood pressure. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the primary function of sweat in the body? Options: A. To regulate body temperature through evaporation., B. To increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels., C. To decrease heart rate and blood pressure., D. To increase water intake and consumption. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ is asking about the alternative names for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), while the generated MCQs are related to a completely different topic, such as sweat glands, body temperature, and exercise.

Warning: No valid match index found in response for Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how many people are diagnosed with ALS worldwide per year?
Options: A. About 30,000, B. About 100,000, C. About 120,000, D. About 1,000,000
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of the mitochondria in cells during exercise? Options: A. To produce ATP, the energy currency of the cell, which is then broken down to release heat and stimulate sweating., B. To regulate body temperature directly., C. To break down glucose and oxygen, but not to produce ATP., D. To increase muscle activity without producing energy. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What process takes place in the sweat gland to prepare the primary secretion for evaporation? Options: A. Osmosis, where water moves into the tube by osmosis, driven by the higher concentration of ions inside the tube., B. Diffusion, where salt is released into the sweat., C. Respiration, where glucose and oxygen are consumed in the mitochondria., D. Filtration, where excess water is removed from the sweat. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What happens to the body's temperature when sweat evaporates from the skin? Options: A. It increases due to the heat energy released from the sweat., B. It remains the same, as the sweat is just a byproduct of exercise., C. It decreases due to the cooling effect of evaporation., D. It becomes unstable, leading to fluctuations in body temperature. Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does the hypothalamus regulate body temperature in response to excessive heat? Options: A. By detecting the excess heat produced by muscle cells and responding with sweating., B. By sending signals to the sweat glands to produce more sweat., C. By stimulating the sympathetic nervous system to increase muscle activity., D. By reducing muscle activity to decrease heat production. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the role of the sympathetic nervous system in the sweating response? Options: A. To stimulate the sweat glands to produce more sweat in response to signals from the hypothalamus., B. To reduce muscle activity and decrease heat production., C. To detect the excess heat produced by muscle cells and respond with sweating., D. To increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels, leading to increased heat and sweating. Correct Option: A
Question 6: In what ways does the body's sweating response help to protect against infections? Options: A. By increasing the body's temperature, making it less habitable for infectious agents., B. By decreasing the body's temperature, making it more habitable for infectious agents., C. By increasing muscle activity, leading to increased heat production., D. By reducing sweat production, leading to decreased heat loss. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the relationship between the hypothalamus and the sweat glands in regulating body temperature? Options: A. The hypothalamus detects excess heat and responds with sweating by stimulating the sweat glands., B. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature by increasing muscle activity., C. The hypothalamus and sweat glands work together to maintain a stable body temperature through sweating., D. The hypothalamus and sweat glands are separate systems that do not interact. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the body's sweating response to exercise help to replenish water lost during exercise? Options: A. By signaling the body to replenish water lost through the hypothalamus., B. By increasing water intake, leading to increased sweat production., C. By reducing sweat production, leading to decreased water loss., D. By increasing muscle activity, leading to increased water consumption. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the significance of sweating in the fight or flight response? Options: A. It helps to increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels, leading to increased heat and sweating., B. It has no role in the fight or flight response., C. It helps to decrease muscle activity and decrease heat production., D. It helps to increase heart rate and blood pressure. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the primary function of sweat in the body? Options: A. To regulate body temperature through evaporation., B. To increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels., C. To decrease heart rate and blood pressure., D. To increase water intake and consumption. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different topic, such as exercise, sweating, and body temperature regulation, whereas the ground truth MCQ is about the number of people diagnosed with ALS worldwide per year.

If I had to choose, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest that a new set of generated MCQs be created that are relevant to the topic of ALS and the ground truth MCQ.

to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Transcript**:
In 1963, a 21-year-old physicist 
named Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with a rare
neuromuscular disorder called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, 
or ALS. Gradually, he lost the ability to walk, use his hands, move his face, and even swallow. But throughout it all,
he retained his incredible intellect, and in the more
than 50 years that followed, Hawking became one of history’s most 
accomplished and famous physicists. However, his condition went uncured and he passed away in 2018 
at the age of 76. Decades after his diagnosis, ALS still ranks as one 
of the most complex, mysterious, and devastating 
diseases to affect humankind. Also called motor neuron disease 
and Lou Gehrig’s Disease, ALS affects about two out of every
100,000 people worldwide. When a person has ALS, their motor neurons, the cells responsible for all voluntary 
muscle control in the body, lose function and die. No one knows exactly why
or how these cells die and that’s part of what 
makes ALS so hard to treat. In about 90% of cases, the disease arises suddenly, 
with no apparent cause. The remaining 10% of cases are hereditary, where a mother or father with ALS passes 
on a mutated gene to their child. The symptoms typically first appear 
after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After diagnosis, most people with ALS live for _______ years.
Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 2-5 years, C. 5-10 years, D. 50 years
Correct Option: B

after age 40. But in some rare cases, like Hawking’s,
ALS starts earlier in life. Hawking’s case was also a medical marvel 
because of how long he lived with ALS. After diagnosis, most people with 
the disease live between 2 to 5 years before ALS leads to respiratory problems 
that usually cause death. What wasn’t unusual in Hawking’s case
was that his ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses 
remained intact. Most people with ALS do not experience
impaired cognition. With so much at stake 
for the 120,000 people who are diagnosed with ALS annually, curing the disease has become one of 
our most important scientific and medical challenges. Despite the many unknowns, we do have some insight into how ALS 
impacts the neuromuscular system. ALS affects two types of nerve cells 
called the upper and lower motor neurons. In a healthy body, 
the upper motor neurons, which sit in the brain’s cortex, transmit messages
from the brain to the lower motor neurons, situated in the spinal cord. Those neurons then transmit 
the message into muscle fibers, which contract or relax in response, resulting in motion. Every voluntary move we make occurs because of messages transmitted 
along this pathway. But when motor neurons degenerate in ALS, their ability to transfer 
messages is disrupted, and that vital signaling system 
is thrown into chaos. Without their regular cues, 
the muscles waste away. Precisely what makes 
the motor neurons degenerate is the prevailing 
mystery of ALS. In hereditary cases, parents pass genetic 
mutations on to their children. Even then, ALS involves multiple genes with multiple possible impacts 
on motor neurons, making the precise triggers
hard to pinpoint. When ALS arises sporadically,
the list of possible causes grows: toxins, viruses, lifestyle, or other environmental factors 
may all play roles. And because there are 
so many elements involved, there’s currently no single test that
can determine whether someone has ALS. Nevertheless, our hypotheses 
on the causes are developing. One prevailing idea is that certain
proteins inside the motor neurons aren’t folding correctly, and are instead forming clumps. The misfolded proteins and clumps 
may spread from cell to cell. This could be clogging up normal
cellular processes, like energy and protein production, 
which keep cells alive. We’ve also learned that along with 
motor neurons and muscle fibers, ALS could involve other
cell types. ALS patients typically have inflammation 
in their brains and spinal cords. Defective immune cells may also play 
a role in killing motor neurons. And ALS seems to change the
behavior of specific cells that provide support for neurons. These factors highlight 
the disease’s complexity, but they may also give us a fuller
understanding of how it works, opening up new avenues for treatment. And while that may be gradual,
we’re making progress all the time. We’re currently developing new drugs, new stem cell therapies 
to repair damaged cells, and new gene therapies 
to slow the advancement of the disease. With our growing arsenal of knowledge, we look forward to discoveries
that can change the future for people living with ALS.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Most people with ALS _______.
Options: A. Lose the ability to voluntarily move their muscles, B. Are cognitively impaired, C. Lose the ability to see, D. Lose the ability to hear
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of the mitochondria in cells during exercise? Options: A. To produce ATP, the energy currency of the cell, which is then broken down to release heat and stimulate sweating., B. To regulate body temperature directly., C. To break down glucose and oxygen, but not to produce ATP., D. To increase muscle activity without producing energy. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What process takes place in the sweat gland to prepare the primary secretion for evaporation? Options: A. Osmosis, where water moves into the tube by osmosis, driven by the higher concentration of ions inside the tube., B. Diffusion, where salt is released into the sweat., C. Respiration, where glucose and oxygen are consumed in the mitochondria., D. Filtration, where excess water is removed from the sweat. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What happens to the body's temperature when sweat evaporates from the skin? Options: A. It increases due to the heat energy released from the sweat., B. It remains the same, as the sweat is just a byproduct of exercise., C. It decreases due to the cooling effect of evaporation., D. It becomes unstable, leading to fluctuations in body temperature. Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does the hypothalamus regulate body temperature in response to excessive heat? Options: A. By detecting the excess heat produced by muscle cells and responding with sweating., B. By sending signals to the sweat glands to produce more sweat., C. By stimulating the sympathetic nervous system to increase muscle activity., D. By reducing muscle activity to decrease heat production. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the role of the sympathetic nervous system in the sweating response? Options: A. To stimulate the sweat glands to produce more sweat in response to signals from the hypothalamus., B. To reduce muscle activity and decrease heat production., C. To detect the excess heat produced by muscle cells and respond with sweating., D. To increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels, leading to increased heat and sweating. Correct Option: A
Question 6: In what ways does the body's sweating response help to protect against infections? Options: A. By increasing the body's temperature, making it less habitable for infectious agents., B. By decreasing the body's temperature, making it more habitable for infectious agents., C. By increasing muscle activity, leading to increased heat production., D. By reducing sweat production, leading to decreased heat loss. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the relationship between the hypothalamus and the sweat glands in regulating body temperature? Options: A. The hypothalamus detects excess heat and responds with sweating by stimulating the sweat glands., B. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature by increasing muscle activity., C. The hypothalamus and sweat glands work together to maintain a stable body temperature through sweating., D. The hypothalamus and sweat glands are separate systems that do not interact. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the body's sweating response to exercise help to replenish water lost during exercise? Options: A. By signaling the body to replenish water lost through the hypothalamus., B. By increasing water intake, leading to increased sweat production., C. By reducing sweat production, leading to decreased water loss., D. By increasing muscle activity, leading to increased water consumption. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the significance of sweating in the fight or flight response? Options: A. It helps to increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels, leading to increased heat and sweating., B. It has no role in the fight or flight response., C. It helps to decrease muscle activity and decrease heat production., D. It helps to increase heart rate and blood pressure. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the primary function of sweat in the body? Options: A. To regulate body temperature through evaporation., B. To increase muscle activity and widen blood vessels., C. To decrease heart rate and blood pressure., D. To increase water intake and consumption. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where is Pluto located?
Options: A. The Kuiper Belt, B. The Prometheus Belt, C. The Andromeda Belt, D. The Odysseus Belt
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why animals hibernate during the winter months? Options: A. To escape the harsh weather conditions, B. To conserve energy and survive the scarcity of food and water, C. To reproduce and give birth, D. To store food and water for later use Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following animals is known to multitask while hibernating, giving birth and lactating at the same time? Options: A. Arctic ground squirrel, B. Fat-tailed dwarf lemur, C. Female black bear, D. All of the above Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens to an animal's heart rate when it enters a state of hibernation? Options: A. It increases to 200 beats per minute, B. It remains the same as its normal heart rate, C. It slows down to about 1 to 3% of its original speed, D. It stops beating altogether Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the phenomenon known as when hibernating animals experience regular bouts of reduced metabolic rate and body temperature, followed by periods of normal metabolic rate and body temperature? Options: A. Torpor, B. Hibernation, C. Interbout arousal, D. Metabolic cycle Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary advantage of studying hibernating animals to understand how their unique control of physiology might help humans? Options: A. It could lead to the development of new medications, B. It could improve the treatment of diseases, C. It could lead to a better understanding of the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans, D. It could lead to a better understanding of the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the potential benefit of understanding how hibernating animals avoid muscle deterioration? Options: A. It could lead to the development of new treatments for muscle diseases, B. It could improve the lives of bedridden patients, C. It could help humans survive in harsh environments, D. It could lead to a better understanding of the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the primary reason why researchers are interested in studying hibernating animals? Options: A. To understand how they survive in harsh environments, B. To develop new treatments for diseases, C. To improve the treatment of brain injuries, D. To understand how they control their physiology and behavior Correct Option: D
Question 8: How might understanding how hibernating animals control their physiology and behavior help humans? Options: A. It could lead to better treatments for protecting the brain during a stroke, B. It could improve the lives of bedridden patients, C. It could illuminate the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the potential benefit of understanding how hibernating animals control their weight with ease? Options: A. It could lead to the development of new treatments for obesity, B. It could improve the lives of bedridden patients, C. It could help humans survive in harsh environments, D. It could lead to a better understanding of the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the potential long-term benefit of studying hibernating animals? Options: A. It could lead to the development of new treatments for diseases, B. It could improve the treatment of brain injuries, C. It could help humans survive in harsh environments, D. It could make human hibernation a real possibility Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the key factor that researchers have discovered is responsible for controlling hibernation in animals? Options: A. Temperature, B. Light exposure, C. Genes, D. Nutrition Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the potential benefit of studying the genomes of hibernating animals? Options: A. It could lead to the development of new treatments for diseases, B. It could improve the treatment of brain injuries, C. It could lead to a better understanding of the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans, D. It could help humans survive in harsh environments Correct Option: None

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What were the objectives of New Horizons?
Options: A. To explore Pluto, B. To collect as much scientific data as possible and transmit it back, C. To explore farther out in the Kuiper Belt, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art

to the gas giant to receive a gravitational

to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is REX?
Options: A. The Radio Science Experiment designed to test for radiation, B. The Radio Science Experiment designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure and temperature, C. The Radio Science Experiment designed to test for signs of life on Pluto, D. The Radio Science Experiment designed to take photographs

**Generated MCQs**:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take Pluto to complete a full orbit?
Options: A. 50 Earth years, B. 127 Earth years, C. 248 Earth years, D. 683 Earth years
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
On July 4, 2015, a NASA spacecraft called New Horizons 
was 5 billion kilometers away from Earth. It was only 10 days away from Pluto, 
after flying for 9.5 years, when it suddenly dropped out of contact. But let’s back up a little. As of 1989, mankind had successfully sent craft 
to every known planet in the solar system except one—Pluto. You may have heard that astronomers 
don’t consider Pluto or its brethren to be planets. However, most planetary 
scientists still do, which is why we're using 
that terminology here. There’s a limited amount 
we can learn about Pluto from Earth because it’s so far from us. Pluto, however, is a scientific goldmine. It’s located in a region 
called the Kuiper Belt, home to many small planets, hundreds of thousands 
of ancient icy objects, and trillions of comets. This mysterious region holds clues 
to the formation of our solar system, and it was long, 
tantalizingly beyond our reach. Until New Horizons. Its objectives: explore Pluto, collect as much scientific 
data as possible, transmit it back to Earth, then explore farther out 
in the Kuiper Belt. To achieve this, the New Horizons team 
outfitted their craft with seven state-of-the-art 
scientific instruments. Those included Ralph, a set of cameras powerful enough to capture features the size 
of city blocks in Manhattan from tens of thousands of kilometers away. And REX, designed to use radio waves to measure Pluto’s atmospheric pressure 
and temperature. All of the onboard equipment had to be
built to be both reliable and lightweight because New Horizons had an
additional challenge; it had to reach its target 
as fast as possible. Why? Around 2020, Pluto will reach 
a point in its orbit where its atmosphere could freeze. And due to the tilt of its axis, more and more of Pluto’s surface 
is shrouded in darkness every year. Pluto completes a full orbit
once every 248 Earth years, so it would be a long wait 
for the next prime opportunity to visit. To see how New Horizons 
got to Pluto in time, let’s jump to its launch. Its three rocket stages accelerated 
New Horizons to such great speeds that it crossed the 400,000 kilometers 
to the moon in just nine hours. About a year later, 
the craft reached Jupiter and got what’s called a gravity assist. That’s where it flies close enough
to the gas giant to receive a gravitational
slingshot effect. New Horizons was then flying 
at around 50,000 kilometers per hour, as it would for the next eight years 
to cross the remaining gulf to Pluto. Going at such an astonishing speed meant that slowing down 
to get into orbit or land would’ve been impossible. That’s why New Horizons was on 
a flyby mission, where it would get just one chance to
scream by Pluto and make its observations. The flyby would have 
to be fully automated, since at that distance, any signals 
to guide it from Earth would take 4.5 hours to reach it. So the team loaded the ship’s computer 
with a series of thousands of commands, called the core load, that would begin to execute 
when the craft was 6.5 days from Pluto. But when New Horizons 
was just ten days out, disaster almost struck. Ground control lost contact 
with the spacecraft. After two nerve-wracking hours,
New Horizons came back online, but mission control discovered 
that its main computer had rebooted, losing the entire core load 
and other critical data. Without that, it would soon 
whizz by Pluto with virtually nothing 
to show for the mission. Alice Bowman, 
the mission’s Operations Manager, led a team for 72 sleepless hours 
to get the instructions loaded back into New Horizons in time. Without room for a single error,
she and her team pulled it off, and New Horizons began taking 
and broadcasting breathtaking images. Those observations have revealed 
a delightfully varied world, with ground fogs, high altitude hazes, possible clouds, canyons, towering mountains, faults, craters, polar caps, glaciers, apparent dune fields, suspected ice volcanoes, evidence for past flowing liquids, and more. One of the most exciting discoveries is the 1000-kilometer-wide
Sputnik Planitia glacier. Sputnik Planitia is mainly composed 
of slowly churning frozen nitrogen, and we’ve never seen anything 
like it in our solar system. The exploration of Pluto 
was a great success, but New Horizons isn’t done yet. On January 1, 2019, it’ll break its own record for 
furthest explored object when it visits a Kuiper Belt Object 
called 2014 MU69, which is orbiting the sun another billion
kilometers farther away than Pluto. The world is holding its breath 
to see what it’ll find there.
